Mrs. Verni is an assistant at Sotheby's in New York. She graduated cum laude from Georgetown University. Her father is the general director of the Harrison division of General Motors in Lockport, N.Y.

nytimes_articles.headline: Artists at the Altar
nytimes_articles.abstract:
DISFIGURING
Art, Architecture, Religion.
By Mark C. Taylor.
Illustrated. 346 pp. Chicago:
The University of Chicago Press. $45.

nytimes_articles.headline: Put Radar Towers In the Ocean or Sound
nytimes_articles.abstract: "F.A.A. Is Opposed on Radar Towers"  [ June 13 ]  stated that the proposed towers have to be within an 8-to-12-mile radius of Kennedy and La Guardia Airports to be effective.  Thus the respective selection of North Bellmore and Roslyn. Considering the intense local opposition to these towers, why not locate them in the Atlantic Ocean and Long Island Sound?

nytimes_articles.headline: 'Must Carry' Must Be Changed
nytimes_articles.abstract: Congress last year gave broadcast television stations the right, if they so demand, to be carried by local cable systems. The purpose of "must carry" rules is to guarantee viewers access to local programming. That sounds reasonable.    But is it reasonable to give that right to home-shopping channels that peddle toasters and jewelry up to 24 hours a day? Is it reasonable to give them that right when doing so would force cable operators to drop valuable channels like CNN, C-Span and Court TV? The Federal Communications Commission was on the verge of answering yes when some irate critics yelped. So the F.C.C. delayed its ruling until this week.

nytimes_articles.headline: Laura C. Gilman and Jeffrey R. Ruhe
nytimes_articles.abstract: Laura Curtis Gilman, a technical consultant for a financial software company in Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Robert Ruhe, the president of Prime Sports Channel Networks Inc. in Woodbury, L.I., a cable television sports service. The Rev. Avery C. Manchester, a Methodist minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the First Church and Parish in Dedham, Mass.   Mrs. Ruhe, a graduate of Harvard University, works for Factset Data Systems. She is the daughter of Susan Hicks of Dedham and Lewis E. Gilman of London. The bride's mother is a sales executive with the Interface Group, a computer trade-show company in Needham, Mass. Mrs. Ruhe is a stepdaughter of Robert F. Hicks.

nytimes_articles.headline:
ART;
Yale Celebrates Its Artists and Its Collectors Since 1950
nytimes_articles.abstract:
WHEN a show is wrapped in self-congratulation, as is "Yale Collects Yale" at the Yale University Art Gallery in New Haven, it better deliver the goods. Fortunately, the show is, on one key level, an ample survey of American painting and sculpture since 1950. 

Behind the imposing facade of the university as an efficient machine -- artists who have attended the Yale School of Art have been widely collected by Yale alumni -- is a supple, rich catholic and informative display of 130 works by 76 artists. The show charts the 43 years since Josef Albers, with his rigorous Bauhaus methods, arrived to head the school.

nytimes_articles.headline: 'Phantom' (the Other One), Full of Glitter
nytimes_articles.abstract: WHEN the musical "Phantom" had its premiere in the New York metropolitan area last summer, it was imperative to point out that this was the 1911 Gaston Leroux novel as interpreted by Maury Yeston (music and lyrics) and Arthur Kopit (book). It was not to be confused with the Andrew Lloyd Webber spectacle currently selling out on Broadway for the sixth year.    Now that the commonly called "other Phantom" is news no more but, all of a sudden, a summer stock staple, with additional, more elaborate productions countrywide, differentiation remains imperative. Still, confusion goes on and perhaps will, evermore.

nytimes_articles.headline: From Great Lakes to the Hudson River: An Iditarod on Water for Paddlers
nytimes_articles.abstract: It's hard to say what might be the most difficult part of a new long-distance race that begins today in Chicago for kayakers and canoeists. Would paddling through parts of the Great Lakes be tougher than 11 tedious days in the Erie Canal? At the end of the next five weeks, competitors who cross the finish line in New York City ought to know.   The 1,000-mile race, the Finlandia Clean Water Challenge, has attracted 20 serious paddlers, 18 of whom plan to go the full course. Designed to be the longest canoe and kayak race in the world, the event is being touted as the Iditarod of paddling. As with the Iditarod, the grueling sled-dog competition in Alaska, weather will surely play a large part.

nytimes_articles.headline: Apulia's Medieval Marvels
nytimes_articles.abstract:
ASKED to name their favorite vacation spot in Italy, more and more Italians nowadays are mentioning Apulia, the province that forms the spur and heel of Italy's proverbial boot. Apulia, or Puglia (POOL-yah), which is the Italian form of its Latin name, is also earning kudos from many non-Italians because of its stark, savage beauty and variety of landscapes.

The architecture of Puglia is as varied as its regions. There are dazzling Romanesque churches at Trani and Troia; twirling baroque palazzi in Lecce and Martina Franca and whimsical cone-shaped stone dwellings, called trulli, in Alberobello. .

nytimes_articles.headline: Two Communities Savor Victory Over Pentagon Plans for Cutbacks; Lots of Hard Work Yield Good Night Of Sleep in Groton
nytimes_articles.abstract: Frank O'Beirne Jr. said today that he was looking forward to his first good night's sleep in months after hearing that the Base Realignment and Closure Commission was unanimously recommending that the Navy maintain its submarine base here.   Mr. O'Beirne, a retired Navy captain and one of the leaders of a coalition formed to save the base, helped perform a computer analysis that showed that closing other facilities could save up to $1.6 billion in the next seven years. He made six trips to Washington to share those results with the commission staff, and one trip to Boston to testify at a regional hearing.

nytimes_articles.headline: Report on Water Danger Irks Residents
nytimes_articles.abstract:
RESIDENTS of Garden City, the Town of Hempstead and the Village of Hempstead are angry over a report that cancer-causing contaminants have been found in their drinking water for 12 years. 

Federal, state and local officials say that the residents have not interpreted the report correctly and that the water is, and has been, safe.

nytimes_articles.headline: Frustration Taking a Toll On Gooden and Green
nytimes_articles.abstract: Dallas Green kept the door to the Mets' clubhouse closed longer than usual yesterday afternoon. He had some things he wanted to straighten out with his players -- things related to selfish play and stupid infield errors and poor execution. All these typical Met problems plagued the team again yesterday, as the Cardinals beat New York, 4-2, despite another solid performance by Dwight Gooden.   This time, though, Green was so furious that he didn't even bother with his typically loud-voiced tirade. His usually ruddy face whitened with anger, Green said afterward that he was sick of the Mets' failure to produce for Gooden, their ace.

nytimes_articles.headline: POSTINGS: Shelton Prospering; Corporate Cornucopia
nytimes_articles.abstract: "It's quite a corporate roster we have," said Mayor Mark A. Lauretti of Shelton, Conn.   Most recently, Pitney Bowes decided to build a new center for its shipping and weighing division on a 22-acre site where research and development operations are already based. Carm Adimando, vice president and treasurer of Pitney Bowes, said the company hoped to break ground for the 234,000-square-foot building next month.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Dog, a Fence, a Hank of Hair
nytimes_articles.abstract: If you want to keep rabbits out of the garden and you don't mind blood on your hands, get a dog with a killer instinct. Or you can put up a fence. Roger Swain, in "The Practical Gardener" (Henry Holt, 1989), recommends 48-inch-high chicken wire with a 1-inch mesh, which he puts up every spring and takes down every fall.    In the spring, he runs his rototiller around the periphery of his vegetable garden, "churning the soil to a fine froth." Then he works the fence 4 to 6 inches down into the soil, which settles it firmly enough to keep animals from getting underneath.

nytimes_articles.headline: Linda Murray, Robert Berzok
nytimes_articles.abstract: Linda Murray, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Murray of Hamden, Conn., was married yesterday to Robert M. Berzok, a son of Mrs. Benjamin Berzok of Deerfield Beach, Fla., and the late Mr. Berzok. Judge Mary Smith of the Yonkers City Court officiated at the Caramoor estate in Katonah, N.Y.   Mrs. Berzok, 50, is the manager of editorial services for Medicus Intercon Inc., the health-care subsidiary of D'Arcy, Masius, Benton & Bowles, an advertising agency in New York. She is also a contributing editor at Longevity magazine in New York. She graduated from Wheaton College.

nytimes_articles.headline: Fresh Air Fund Explores Career Choices
nytimes_articles.abstract: Most of the junior high school students from the Bronx who toured New York Telephone's Guardian Center in Manhattan last week have yet to settle on careers. But for 14-year-old Toya Ford, the visit provided a chance to sample corporate life, and she seized it with gusto.   When the students filed into a boardroom to see a film on career options, Toya grabbed a seat at the head of the table so she could learn what it feels like "to be the boss."

nytimes_articles.headline: Scholars Say Sheik Gives Inspiration, Not Orders
nytimes_articles.abstract: He sat on the beige sofa of his spare living room, thundering his call for revolution in Egypt. The planned execution of 22 of his followers would lead to a "blood bath" against the Egyptian Government of President Hosni Mubarak, Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman warned in Arabic. "The first people who will drown are Mubarak and his regime."   America, too, would pay the price, said the blind 55-year-old Islamic fundamentalist. "They have to understand they will have to bear the consequences for their actions," he threatened on June 17.

nytimes_articles.headline:
FARE OF THE COUNTRY;
Maine's Other Favorite Seafood: Scallops
nytimes_articles.abstract:
IN Maine, scallops often make their way to a restaurant table through the back door. 

"I serve scallops whenever I can," said Jonathan Chase, owner and chef of Jonathan's Restaurant in Blue Hill. "That means whenever a diver comes to the back door and offers me some."

nytimes_articles.headline: Connecticut as Seen by The New Yorker
nytimes_articles.abstract:
IF the colorful carnival scene hanging in the Pavilion Building at the Old State House looks familiar, it probably is. After all, it was inspired by the annual Guilford Fair, an ideal image for the artist James Stevenson to turn into a cover for The New Yorker. 

Arthur Getz's cover painting of a hardware store stocked full of spring gardening supplies may look familiar, too. Mr. Getz, 80, of Sharon, who has drawn more covers for the New Yorker than anyone, says he can't remember which hardware store he chose to capture on canvas in 1966, but he's quite sure it was in Connecticut.

nytimes_articles.headline: Lawyers Lend Hand to Nonprofit Groups
nytimes_articles.abstract:
WHEN a support program for AIDS patients and their families faced the possibility of being dropped from the Greater Bridgeport AIDS Project for lack of funds, a small group of volunteers knew they wanted to keep it going.

 They formed the Evergreen Network and branched off on their own but still faced a major problem -- little money. Adaline Demarrais, the executive director of the Bridgeport-area program, said they did not even have the money to hire a lawyer to steer them through the process of becoming a nonprofit group.

nytimes_articles.headline: State Approves Fish Farm in Sound
nytimes_articles.abstract:
FARMING of another kind may soon take root on the North Fork. A seafood salesman, Robert Link, and Dennis Quaranta of Quaranta Enterprises, a management business in Deer Park, have obtained state approval to lease 200 acres of Long Island Sound waters in eastern Gardiners Bay with plans to raise summer flounder or fluke, as well as salmon, cod, haddock, blowfish and weakfish.

The lease, which covers a site just south of Plum Island, takes effect next month, pending approval by the State Environmental Conservation Department on what fish can be raised.

nytimes_articles.headline: Young, Homosexual And Taking Charge
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   I applaud your article "Out and Organized" (June 13). Being a young teen-ager grappling with my own issues of sexuality, it's nice that some of us are being recognized and that some of us aren't going to sit around and complain -- as society as a whole seems to be doing -- but instead, take charge and lead change. We are demanding both respect for who we are and encouragement for taking action. SHANA PEIFFER Wappingers Falls, N.Y.

nytimes_articles.headline: Elaine P. Mullen, Thomas H. Peer
nytimes_articles.abstract: Elaine Patricia Mullen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter P. Mullen of Bronxville, N.Y., was married on Friday to Thomas Harold Peer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold T. Peer of Cranford, N.J. The Rev. Otto Hentz performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the chapel of the Convent of the Sacred Heart in New York.   Mrs. Peer is a senior occupational therapist at the New York State Psychiatric Institute and the director of the transitional work program at the institute's Community Mental Health Clinic, both in New York. She graduated from Georgetown University and received a master's degree in occupational therapy from Columbia University, where she is also a clinical instructor of occupational therapy.

nytimes_articles.headline: Bettman Adds Stein's Hat
nytimes_articles.abstract: Gary Bettman, the first-year commissioner of the National Hockey League, said today that Gil Stein's recent demotion from league president to an unspecified advisory role was a mere formality that had been agreed upon more than six months ago, when Bettman replaced Stein as chief executive officer of the league.   Bettman appeared concerned about reports that appeared today in The Chicago Tribune and The Montreal Gazette that implied that the move was a sudden and unexpected reduction in rank for the controversial Stein. A day before, after the Board of Governors meeting, Bettman had told several dozen reporters that nothing of newsworthy importance had occurred at the meeting.

nytimes_articles.headline: The View From: Stamford; A Shelter That Works To Motivate Residents
nytimes_articles.abstract: AT Franklin Common in Stamford, people without homes can get help and a place to live for up to two years. And while a family is housed at the Common -- with everything from laundry to child care available -- the basic rule is they have to make an effort to help themselves.    The Rev. Richard L. Schuster, director of St. Luke's Community Services, which operates the Common, said that "what we're trying to accomplish here is to help persons have a full opportunity to reach towards self-sufficiency."

nytimes_articles.headline: Graduates Bring Their Ideals to a Battered World
nytimes_articles.abstract: AS Ricardo Horacio Roda prepared for graduation last week, he looked back on three years of struggling to learn a new language and make friends in a strange country. The 17-year-old from Argentina, the first Hispanic student in 60 years to become valedictorian of Roosevelt High School in Yonkers, said that for him graduation was "the American dream come true -- proof that in this country, if you want something and work hard for it, it can happen."   Throughout Westchester last week, high school students who were approaching graduation looked back at their struggles as teen-agers and ahead at the responsibilities they would shoulder as adults. Born in the 1970's, these graduates are statistically part of what some journalists are calling "Generation X" (from the 1991 book by Douglas Coupland, regarded by some as the manifesto of the under-30 set). This group has no formal name (titles like Boomlets and MTV Generation have at times been suggested by the media for the older, twentysomethings) and to date few distinguishing characteristics except that they follow a generation of baby boomers, school authorities say. A Difficult Legacy    It is what 17-year-old Jennifer Zobel, who graduated second in her class at Fox Lane High School in Bedford last week, described as "a generation of children of working parents, kids who had to learn early on to be independent."

nytimes_articles.headline: To Hell With Science
nytimes_articles.abstract:
UNDERSTANDING THE PRESENT
Science and
the Soul of Modern Man.
By Bryan Appleyard.
269 pp. New York:
Doubleday. $23.50.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Mystic Pizza Parlor Finds Fame Is Not Fleeting
nytimes_articles.abstract: FIVE years ago a low-budget movie that had been shot in Mystic and Stonington had its premiere in Mystic, in a little movie theater in a shopping center. It was a fitting locale. "Mystic Pizza" was not a blockbuster film; it was a little film about the lives of three young women who work in a pizza parlor, and featured a cast of virtual unknowns: Julia Roberts, who took second billing to a 16-year-old named Annabeth Gish, and Lili Taylor.    The movie surprised a lot of people, including the critics. It was well directed by Donald Petrie, whose first feature film it was, well acted, and a welcome relief from some of the sludge being pumped out in the name of entertainment. It also made money. It cost $6 million to shoot and in the first six weeks netted more than $9 million. It helped to push Julia Roberts into stardom. It also helped to push the real Mystic Pizza into stardom. Brother in New London    Mystic Pizza was the local pizza parlor for the village, operated by a Greek couple, Steve and Fofi Zelepos, who had come to America in the early 70's and to the Connecticut shore because one of Mr. Zelepos's brothers was a tailor in New London and could help him acclimate to the new country.

nytimes_articles.headline: They Hear America Talking
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   How Mark Twain would howl -- and rage and cuss -- at the temerity of Shelley Fisher Fishkin and the timidity of James R. Kincaid!

nytimes_articles.headline: Stylish Furnishings on a Beer Budget
nytimes_articles.abstract: "STYLE has nothing to do with money," Tom Hogan said last Sunday. Mr. Hogan is an owner of Chartreuse, a new home-furnishings store in the East Village that combines the sensibilities of an aristocratic Park Avenue apartment with the price tags of a thrift shop.    Mr. Hogan has a degree in interior design from the Parsons School of Design, and his partner, Johanna McElfresh, used to work in the French furniture department at Sotheby's. So when you combine his eye with her expertise, you can hang a seashells-in-a-shadowbox project someone may have made in junior high ($75 for a pair) next to an old porcelain plate ($28) and an amateur flower painting ($80) and have everything look like a page from Architectural Digest (their favorite magazine).

nytimes_articles.headline: Putting It in the Market
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   "Trade Sanity With Japan" (editorial, June 16) states that the American economy suffers from a lack of savings, presumably as witnessed by the low percentage of money invested in banks, and that this low rate of bank savings has prevented American companies from raising capital for modernization. I disagree.

nytimes_articles.headline:
OUT THERE: UNIVERSAL CITY;
Mall That Imitates Life
nytimes_articles.abstract:
Jugglers perform under palms brought in from the desert. Weight lifters pump iron on trucked-in sand. A beach-front hot-dog vendor touts designer sausages, and a wave pool that simulates the ocean provides soothing background noises as bright neon signs flicker above.

This is Citywalk, make-believe Los Angeles in the Universal Studios enclave, overlooking the San Fernando Valley. It is a three-block-long shopping mall modeled after the city around it. A $100 million project that opened last month after nearly 10 years in the making, Citywalk blends architecture, styles and activities of various parts of the Los Angeles area, including Venice Beach, historic Olvera Street, trendy Melrose Avenue and the Sunset Strip, into a smaller, more concentrated -- and in some ways quite strange -- version of L.A.

nytimes_articles.headline: A la Carte; Restaurants in Montauk Are Beginning to Make Waves
nytimes_articles.abstract: MONTAUK is stirring. The restaurants in this rustic port at the tip of the Island still cater to more fishermen, families, day trippers and campers than trendy Hamptons types.    But the quality of Montauk Point's eating places is improving and starting to attract more and more sophisticated diners. A new wave of more affluent permanent residents who often went to the Hamptons to dine helped spur the change.

nytimes_articles.headline: Harkness Park: Another View
nytimes_articles.abstract: I cringed when I read the description of the "well-kept formal gardens" at Harkness Memorial Park in the story on summer music festivals (June 13).

nytimes_articles.headline: Loyalty to a Strategy Must Be Tempered
nytimes_articles.abstract: IT'S a standard piece of advice in tennis that you change a losing strategy, and that goes for chess, too. But it is quite amazing how many players fail to follow it in both games.   Consider the encounter between the grandmaster Gata Kamsky of Brooklyn and the world junior champion, international master Pablo Zarnicki of Argentina, from Round 8 of the Miguel Najdorf International Tournament in Buenos Aires, April 18-30. After Kamsky had subtly foiled his strategy, Zarnicki pressed on with it and was nicely crushed.

nytimes_articles.headline: Surprise Guests In the Garden
nytimes_articles.abstract: I WAS digging up my tomato patch one morning about a month ago, when I thought I saw something move. Some little dark blip in the periphery of my vision. A lurching kind of motion.   I looked around, but nothing was moving, except the wind in the crape myrtle. So I decided I'd imagined it and stepped down on my spade again, with that hearty pleasure that comes from turning over good earth. (I know, you no-dig types will be writing in next week, but I come from a long line of shovelers.)

nytimes_articles.headline: Mirror, Mirror
nytimes_articles.abstract: OUT of all interior spaces, perhaps none are as fearsome as the fitting room. Laden with secret psychology, they are spaces in which life's truths are tripled in tripartite mirrors. Setha Low, a professor of environmental psychology at the CUNY graduate center, calls them "the ultimate confrontational space."    Anne Cole, the California-based swimsuit designer, admits that there are "worse things in life than fitting rooms -- I just can't think of what they are."

nytimes_articles.headline: Yellowstone's Landmark in Logs
nytimes_articles.abstract: PERHAPS no building embodies the myths of the American West better than the Old Faithful Inn in Yellowstone National Park, where the mere act of entering the lobby -- an enchanted treehouse come to life -- provides the same sense of awe as the wilderness itself.    For devotees of rustic architecture, the hotel, designed in 1903 by the architect Robert C. Reamer and built within oooooh-ing distance of Old Faithful, defines Yellowstone as a place as surely as the geysers and mountains that inspired it. Its atrium lobby, one of the most dramatic and dotty log interiors ever created, is surely the only one in which the bellmen sleep in a belfry called "Bat's Alley" and guests can sip from a drinking fountain embedded in a boulder or gaze at an shiplike indoor crow's nest seven stories up.

nytimes_articles.headline: Dr. Winslow, Dr. Seldin
nytimes_articles.abstract: Dr. Constance Pinover Winslow, an orthodontist, and Dr. Leslie Wilfred Seldin, a dentist, both in practice in New York, were married there yesterday. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel officiated at the Leopard Restaurant.   The bride, 47, is the daughter of Harriet Pinover of New York and the late Maurice Pinover. She graduated from the University of Pennsylvania and received her dental degree from New York University.

nytimes_articles.headline: IN SHORT: FICTION
nytimes_articles.abstract:
COMEDY OF MANNERS
VENUS ENVY
By Rita Mae Brown.
Bantam, $21.95.

nytimes_articles.headline: Dinkins Opposes Measure on Garbage
nytimes_articles.abstract: A bill in the New York State Assembly intended to prevent the bunching of incinerators, landfills and sewage plants in poor or minority communities is encountering opposition from an unexpected corner: the Dinkins administration.   Under the legislation, companies or government agencies seeking to open such "environmental facilities" would have to prove that they were not placing an unfair burden on a neighborhood. To receive a permit, the applicants would also have to develop plans to share profits with surrounding communities, or provide them with amenities like parks.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Decade After Disaster State Rebuilds at Rapid Pace
nytimes_articles.abstract:
THE State Transportation Department is seeking good homes for its historic bridges. The bridges are free, with moving costs thrown in to seal the deal.

It is a part of a plan, approved by Congress, to preserve the nation's rich diversity of historic bridges, and the old bridges in Connecticut are becoming available at a time when the aging infrastructure is being updated and the state's bridges are being rebuilt and replaced at a rapid pace.

nytimes_articles.headline: Glorious Past, Hopeful Future
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   As a 48-year-old Broadway aficionado, I was left with a bittersweet feeling by Frank Rich's overview of the Broadway scene  [ "A New Generation on Old Broadway," June 6 ] . It brought to mind the first dramatic play I saw, "A Raisin in the Sun," and my first musical, "The Music Man." Thinking over the years and of the wonderful plays that have warmed the hearts of many, I realize that a moment in time has now passed. I am a romantic at heart and reminisce about "High Spirits," "Golden Boy," "L'il Abner," "Royal Hunt of the Sun," "Roar of the Greasepaint," "Chicago" and on and on.

nytimes_articles.headline: Arnold as Icon: From Hulk to Hero
nytimes_articles.abstract: WHEN THE FICTIONAL Jack Slater leaps off the screen into New York City in "Last Action Hero," he masquerades as the actor who plays him. "I'm Ah-nold Braunschweiger," he introduces himself pleasantly. The last action hero is the last man on earth who can't say the word Schwarzenegger.    Not long ago, he wasn't alone. Now there is "Last Action Hero," a self-mocking film built around the idea that everyone knows Arnold. The cleverest moments in this comic adventure do not come while the star plays the explosive Slater, but during a brief episode in which he plays himself. As Arnold walks into the premiere of his new Jack Slater movie with his wife, Maria Shriver, she mutters to him: "And remember, don't plug the restaurants. I just hate it when you plug the restaurants and the gyms. It's so tacky."

nytimes_articles.headline: Bryant Park's So Near, So Far
nytimes_articles.abstract: Last week's social marathon, perhaps the last until fall, included an event in an outdoor arena, the lushly restored Bryant Park, behind the New York Public Library.    On Wednesday, Ricky and Ralph Lauren (seen dancing, above) gave a dinner there to benefit the Robert Steel Foundation for Pediatric Cancer Research. Robert Isabell, the floral designer, added a thousand or so citronella candles, a handpainted dance floor and white wicker furniture to the park's green-as-could-be lawn and gardens, creating a wonderland worthy of Mr. Lauren's own advertisements. All that was missing was an entrance by the fashion designer himself on one of his noble steeds. "It was like being at a grand European house," said Peter Brown, who does public relations for Andrew Lloyd Webber and others.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Double Solution
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Sports Editor:   George Steinbrenner is right to be concerned about safety at Yankee Stadium. But there is a simple solution, and one that doesn't require the Bombers to abandon the Bronx. Instead of paying Danny Tartabull $5 million a year to go 0 for 4, the principal owner should take all but two cents of that money and hire a thousand private uniformed security guards, at five grand for the summer, and station them in highly visible positions throughout the immediate neighborhood. That would make everyone happy, and Tartabull would finally be earning his pay. TONY SAVAGE The Bronx

nytimes_articles.headline: From the Welfare Rolls to the Honor Roll
nytimes_articles.abstract: AT Pace University here, Lillian Pou graduated with honors last month. The 32-year-old single parent of two daughters, who had been receiving public assistance for 10 years, won the Pace University Office Technology Award and was elected to the Phi Eta Sigma Honor Society at the university for her academic achievement.   Ms. Pou, a Yonkers resident, is one of 17 welfare recipients who graduated with Associate of Science degrees from the university -- the first graduates in a new educational program sponsored by the county's Department of Social Services to help mothers on welfare enter the workforce.

nytimes_articles.headline: Elizabeth Owen And John Pinto
nytimes_articles.abstract: Elizabeth Ann Owen, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Owen Jr. of Hinsdale, Ill., was married there yesterday to John Joseph Pinto, a son of Pauline B. Pinto of New York and Joseph J. Pinto of North Salem, N.Y. The Rev. Edward Searl, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at the Hinsdale Golf Club.   Mrs. Pinto, 26, graduated from Wellesley College and received a master's degree in natural resource policy from the University of Michigan. Her father is a partner at William Blair & Company, a securities brokerage in Chicago. Her mother, Lois Owen, is an administrator at the National Ice Carving Association in Chicago.

nytimes_articles.headline: Dale Kendrick, Vernon Barback
nytimes_articles.abstract: Elizabeth Dale Kendrick, a daughter of Ellen Kendrick of New York and the late Shildrick A. Kendrick, was married yesterday to Vernon Richard Barback, the son of Prof. and Mrs. Ronald Barback of Tunbridge Wells, Kent, England. The Rev. Heather Morrison Yaden performed the ceremony at the Andover (N.J.) Presbyterian Church.   Mrs. Barback is known as Dale. She graduated from Vassar College and received a law degree from New York University. Her father was the executive director of research and development for the College Entrance Examination Board in New York. Her mother is a senior technical writer at the New York Clearing House, a bank transaction concern in New York. The bride's previous marriage ended in divorce, as did the bridegroom's.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Gifts of Vision
nytimes_articles.abstract: Celebrating art, Adolfo's refined sense of style and the means to see it all.

nytimes_articles.headline: On Sunday; Quiet Steward Says Farewell To His Parks
nytimes_articles.abstract: ORIN Lehman, the New York State Parks Commissioner, is driving from park to park, quietly saying goodbye. After 18 years, Albany's longest-reigning commissioner retires in mid-July. Few among the public will notice. He is not a modern man, does not attract attention to himself.   Friday he stood under an old pavilion here in Baird State Park, propping himself up with the metal canes he has relied on since a World War II injury, and thanked the 40 workers (groundskeepers, mechanics, maintenance men), asking for last suggestions to make the parks better.

nytimes_articles.headline: Helaine Harte, Bogdan Miltchev
nytimes_articles.abstract: Helaine Lynn Harte, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Lawrence S. Harte of Livingston, N.J., was married there yesterday evening to Bogdan Miltchev, a son of Col. and Mrs. Ivan Miltchev of Sofia, Bulgaria. Cantor Dennis Tobin officiated at the Cedar Hill Country Club.   The bride, 26, graduated from Columbia University, from which she also received an M.B.A. She is employed in brand management for the Procter & Gamble Company in Cincinnati. Her father is an orthodontist.

nytimes_articles.headline: When Postmasters Were Creative
nytimes_articles.abstract: IN the 19th century, in the infancy of the octopus that became the Civil Service bureaucracy, postmasters in smaller offices did not earn regular salaries from what was then the Post Office Department. Instead, they were allowed to keep the money customers paid for postal services.   In simplified terms, managers of local post offices were given appointments that required them to hold mail addressed to local residents, who picked up their letters. There was almost no home delivery.

nytimes_articles.headline: Death in Venice (at the Biennale)
nytimes_articles.abstract: It is fitting that the most talked-about work at the current Venice Biennale should be Hans Haacke's installation in the main chamber of the German pavilion, a pile of rubble made from the room's torn-up stone floor, with the word "Germania" emblazoned on the wall. It might as well have read "Biennale."   One way to picture this fiasco of an event is to imagine a pendulum paused at the end of its arc. The 45th version of the oldest and most famous of the international art roundups is so inert and lifeless that it can provoke only malaise, nothing stronger. At the same time, what is on view suggests that matters in certain quarters of contemporary art have reached an untenable extreme, proved above all by the vast wasteland of the Aperto, the Biennale's international display of younger artists.

nytimes_articles.headline: China Tourism Sets Record
nytimes_articles.abstract: After a dip caused by the 1989 Army crackdown on the Tiananmen democracy movement, tourism is again soaring in China. According to the Government, a record 37 million foreigners visited China last year, up sharply from the previous total of 31 million in 1988, a year before the crackdown. Every indication is that numbers will go still higher this year.   The bad news is that it is now difficult to reserve flights or make last-minute schedule changes. The days when a tourist could show up in Hong Kong and quickly arrange a 10-day tour of China are now over.

nytimes_articles.headline: Arsenal Mars New Image of Salvador's Ex-Rebels
nytimes_articles.abstract: The explosion of tons of weapons hidden by El Salvador's former guerrillas under an auto repair shop in Nicaragua last month has seriously damaged the former rebels' credibility as a newly formed political party. nytimes_articles.headline: 'Life's Dominion'
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   After reading Laurence H. Tribe's review of "Life's Dominion: An Argument About Abortion, Euthanasia, and Individual Freedom," by Ronald Dworkin (May 16), I can only wonder where the reviewer and the author have been living for the past few decades. Haven't either of them ever considered feminist analyses of why abortion is such a bitterly, even viciously, contested issue? Mr. Dworkin's rarefied arguments about the intrinsic value of life miss the most fundamental point: every time a woman makes an independent choice on a reproductive issue she removes a stone from the foundations of patriarchy.

nytimes_articles.abstract: The Devils didn't draft a coach today, so they still must fill a big gap in their organization. nytimes_articles.abstract: THE Police Department has made an unusual decision: In looking for a site for a new headquarters for the Brooklyn North section of its Safe Streets, Safe City Program, it decided to convert the 83d Precinct station house at 179 Wilson Avenue, which has been decaying for a decade. This gives the oddly grand building a fighting chance to survive to celebrate its centennial in 1995.   Completed in 1895 at the southeast corner of DeKalb Avenue in an area of older tenements, the $50,000 building dominated the intersection with its picturesque, castle-like silhouette and tall corner tower. nytimes_articles.headline: 'Women and Wood' in Katonah Uses Forms as Metaphors
nytimes_articles.abstract: WORKING in a thicket of branches stuck with toy guns, the artist mused on her theme. "I've always been taken by scenes in movies with arrows coming out of the woods, and with the whole idea of secret revenge," said Jerilea Zempel, whose construction, "Environmental Protection," is part of the show "Women and Wood: The Metaphorical Use of Forms" at the Katonah Museum of Art.   The show of works by eight sculptors was organized by Corinne Robins, an author, teacher and critic whose not-so-secret revenge has long been to bring more attention to women artists. "I've done co-ed shows, but I am a feminist curator," said Ms. Robins, who added that women must still struggle for their place on the art scene.

nytimes_articles.headline: Classical Taste in the U.S.
nytimes_articles.abstract: From about 1800 to 1840, Americans were fanatical about anything Greek or Roman. The ancient civilizations influenced tastes in furniture, clothing, reading and travel. Greece and Rome represented not only sources of prestige and esthetics, but also models of refinement at a time when the United States was shaping itself into a new republic.    "Classical Taste in America, 1800-1840," an exhibition opening today at the Baltimore Museum of Art, features more than 250 classically inspired objects, including furniture, paintings, silver, sculpture, glass, ceramics, textiles and printed materials.

nytimes_articles.headline: Ask What PBS Can Do for Its Country
nytimes_articles.abstract: Granted, only someone who makes a living from watching television could leap to the conclusion that David R. Gergen's performance as a commentator on "The MacNeil/Lehrer Newshour" was what got him his big new job with the Clinton White House. There must be other reasons. Yet glimpsing the master of communications on the tube nowadays, venting the Administration line with the same breathy boyishness as when he was criticizing it, one can't help wondering. nytimes_articles.headline: Barbra Streisand Mixes Star Power And High Concept
nytimes_articles.abstract: Barbra Streisand, at 51, enjoys a cultural status that only one other American entertainer, Frank Sinatra, has achieved in the last half century. On top of her longevity as a star, the recent success of her film "The Prince of Tides" and her friendship with Bill Clinton have propelled her to a new peak of power in Hollywood. It was inevitable that this status should be reflected in Ms. Streisand's new album, "Back to Broadway." But power cuts both ways. While the record includes some of the most thrilling singing of Ms. Streisand's career, it also has some of the most overbearing.    The successor to Ms. Streisand's 1985 "Broadway Album," the new record (Columbia 44189; CD and cassette) sounds like a state-of-the-world address by a performer with some heavy wisdom to impart. The tone of the singing is generally more stentorian than on any previous Streisand album. And in the record's Hollywood operatic arrangements, a Pucciniesque sweetness runs neck and neck with a Spielbergian grandiosity.

nytimes_articles.headline: More Burdens From the Rehnquist Court
nytimes_articles.abstract: Unchastened by Congress's rebukes for misinterpreting civil rights laws, the Supreme Court is back in the business of loading up job discrimination cases with extra burdens for those claiming bias. On Friday the Court ruled that an employer could give false explanations for firing a black employee -- yet still prevail in a lawsuit.    Over the years the courts have worked out procedures and burdens of proof that were fair to both employees and employers. A plaintiff's plausible claim of discriminatory firing put the onus on the employer to provide a nonracial reason or lose the case. One would think that a phony or incredible explanation would be worse than none at all. Not according to the 5-to-4 majority.

nytimes_articles.headline: Interpreting: a Business Spurred by Diversity
nytimes_articles.abstract: THE increasing ethnic and racial diversity of New Jersey has produced a huge demand for interpreting and translating services in courts, state agencies and corporations, officials and business executives say.   With scores of multinational corporate headquarters now nestled in New Jersey's suburbs, and with large communities of non-English-speaking Hispanic, Asian and other immigrants settling in the state's urban centers, this demand has led to the creation of hundreds of agencies that use the services of thousands of independent interpreters and translators.

nytimes_articles.headline: Stop Punishing Vietnam
nytimes_articles.abstract: France and Japan want to lend Vietnam $140 million to pay off the old Saigon regime's debts to the International Monetary Fund. That would make Hanoi eligible for new international loans to help its market-oriented economic reforms.    It's a constructive idea. But it has been held up until now by stubborn opposition from Washington. Beyond a reasonable concern about missing servicemen, previous administrations have seemed determined to keep punishing Hanoi for winning the war almost 20 years ago. President Clinton can end this counterproductive sulk by following his advisers' recommendation to let Paris and Tokyo proceed.

nytimes_articles.headline:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: New Market, Md.;
Concerns Over Building Boom
nytimes_articles.abstract:
WOODSPRING, a development of 98 one-family homes, is nearing completion just outside this historic Frederick County town of 500. 

It is part of a countywide building boom that some fear could overload existing roads, schools and sewer and water systems and destroy the county's rural ambience.

nytimes_articles.headline: What's Ban-Lon Got to Do With It?
nytimes_articles.abstract: THE coming-soon-to-middle-age couple seated next to me at the Embassy 1 theater watching "What's Love Got to Do With It?" was blithely, almost lovey-dovily holding hands -- no mean feat, considering the picture hardly qualifies as the make-out movie of the summer. Even during the film's initial re-enactment of sexual abuse, the woman didn't stiffen and pull away, the man wasn't pretending to count roses in the carpet. Their popcorn chomping never lost a beat. Evidently, someone else's emotional turmoil didn't push any buttons on their control boards.   Then Laurence Fishburne, as Ike Turner -- married at the time to Tina Turner, played by Angela Bassett -- loped into a diner, wearing a royal blue jumpsuit girded by a leather-and-coin-studded belt in a heavyweight championship width. Their chomping grew erratic. Their hands disengaged. The man muttered something. The woman muttered something back, punctuated by a snigger. The man's tone got bolder.

nytimes_articles.headline: Live and in Color
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Hail and three rousing cheers for your Book Review this week -- almost encyclopedic in scope, a guide to reading and a color cover! Congratulations.  ADOLPH N. SPERO  Bronx

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: An article last Sunday in copies distributed in Connecticut and Westchester, about small-landlord associations, included an erroneous status report from a legislative aide on a measure in the Connecticut Legislature. The measure, allowing towns to require tenants to pay rent into escrow accounts when landlords lack certificates of occupancy, did reach the floor, and was passed.

nytimes_articles.headline:
In the Region: New Jersey;
A New Link for New Brunswick's Revival
nytimes_articles.abstract:
NEXT August two time-worn structures at the southernmost tip of New Brunswick's downtown will be razed to make way for an office and academic building for Rutgers University, providing a critical link in the continued revival of this city's central business district.

The key element in the $42 million project, called Civic Square, will be a five-story, 160,000-square-foot structure at the corner of Livingston and New Streets that is to house the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy, the Center for Urban Policy Research and the Mason Gross School of the Arts. The latter now occupies one of the buildings that will be demolished.

nytimes_articles.headline: Movies and Music Try to Live as One
nytimes_articles.abstract: Each June the latest sound equipment is trotted out at the Consumer Electronics Show here. This year the audio industry also exhibited something else: acute symptoms of a split personality.    One segment of the audio trade is marching blithely into the multimedia future -- one in which audio-video home theaters provide satellite-relayed, computer-based services. The other group is sticking strictly with audio, clinging to such traditional concerns as musical fidelity and tonal nuance.

nytimes_articles.headline: Raid on Baghdad; Clinton Seemed to Shift
nytimes_articles.abstract: President Clinton's relationships with the Iraqi leader, Saddam Hussein, were uneasy and uncertain from the beginning of his Presidency. Even as he awaited his swearing-in ceremony, American bombers were striking at Iraqi missile positions.   He began his Presidency apparently offering an olive branch to Mr. Hussein, but Mr. Clinton ordered a missile strike against Iraqi intelligence headquarters yesterday in retaliation for what he said was an Iraqi attempt to kill former President George Bush. Indeed, his speech last night announcing the raids seemed as tough as Mr. Bush's harsh comments about Mr. Hussein.

nytimes_articles.headline: Don't Tax, Don't Cut, Don't Panic Over Deficit
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   With virtually no votes to lose, the Administration must now reconcile a House version of its economic plan that counts on the ill-fated British thermal unit tax and a Senate version that substitutes other unpopular taxes and spending cuts. A better substitute for the energy tax: Nothing!

nytimes_articles.headline: Terrified by "Jurassic Park'? Ha! Try These
nytimes_articles.abstract: SOME THINGS YOU DON'T ever forget. One seems to be the first movie that frightened you, leaving such an indelible mark that for days you couldn't be alone without imagining terrible things happening. Paradoxically, it wasn't always the film meant to scare you. For me, it was the unlikely "Annie Get Your Gun." I was 4. My grandmother took me to see the movie at Radio City Music Hall. She had to lead me out of the theater, tears running down my cheeks, mid-movie. I'm not sure whether it was the 10-foot-tall Indians, with their fiercely painted faces, or Betty Hutton's singing.

nytimes_articles.headline: The King of Junque
nytimes_articles.abstract: Kenneth Jay Lane isn't the indignant type. It isn't worth the bother, as he would say in the slightly languid voice that may once have been affected but is now as much a part of him as the slightly British overtone he acquired at the same time that he discovered British tailors.   Still, mention Kenneth Jay Lane and "walker" in the same sentence and he gets a bit indignant, sort of. Maybe reproachful would be more accurate, or disappointed.

nytimes_articles.headline: Buffalo
nytimes_articles.abstract: The last few years have been good for Buffalo. A recent survey by the the National Weather Service confirms that there are worse places in New York State for snowfall (Syracuse topped the list last winter). Then, too, there was a flurry of new investment that followed the announcement in January 1989 of the North American Free Trade Agreement, which phases out tariffs between the United States and Canada.    But landing the World University Games for the United States for the first time in their 70 years of competitions may be the biggest boost yet. The games are held every two years. They are scheduled for July 8 through the 18th and are expected not only to bring more than 5,000 athletes from 120 countries, but also to put the state's second-largest city in the international limelight.

nytimes_articles.headline: Hamptons Step Up Effort on Traffic
nytimes_articles.abstract:
MOTORISTS heading to the East End for the Fourth of July weekend can expect to find stepped-up police activity to handle the influx of cars and buses funneling into the main two-lane highway and spilling out onto country lanes and vilage roads. 

Police officers say they are prepared to crack down on speeding, seat-belt compliance and drunken drivers. Drivers parked at the beach without the proper permits, parked illegally or exceeding the one- and two-hour street parking limits should not be surprised to see their cars ticketed or towed away.

nytimes_articles.headline: New Threats Prompt Increases in Security
nytimes_articles.abstract: Life in New York City has changed in many ways, some small, some large, since terrorist bombings have been added to the list of urban fears.    A large potted fern is mysteriously absent from the elevator bank (because big plants can hide little bombs). There is an unexplained delay in the delivery of an oddly shaped package from the mail room (because someone was suspicious of its contents).

nytimes_articles.headline: Political Memo; States' Top Democrats Get Appeal for Patience
nytimes_articles.abstract: For a party that assumed the White House only five months ago, the message at a convention of state Democratic leaders here was a candid admission that amounted to a political confessional: Lower your expectations and be patient with your President. He's learning from his mistakes.   In public and in private, David Wilhelm, chairman of the Democratic Party, devoted hours this weekend trying to convince restive state leaders that President Clinton had a bright future, even while conceding the party's shortcomings.

nytimes_articles.headline:
MUSIC;
When 200 Organists Get Together
nytimes_articles.abstract:
PUT 200 professional organists in the same city for a convention, and the schedule will include workshops on such topics as "But I Can't Sing High," "What's New and Ringing" and "Small Organ Design"; 10 recitals -- most of which are open to the public -- and an "organ crawl," a popular feature of the convention.

The gathering is a regional convention today through Wednesday in Newark with the Metropolitan New Jersey chapter of the American Guild of Organists as host.

nytimes_articles.headline: Europeans Tell Bosnians State Will Be Viable
nytimes_articles.abstract: Senior European foreign ministry officials sought to reassure Bosnia and Herzegovina's collective leadership today that the international community would make sure that the Bosnians were left with a viable state of their own if they agreed to negotiate an end to the civil war based on an ethnic partition of the country.   Diplomats said the European ministers hoped that by offering such assurances now, they would overcome the hostility of President Alija Izetbegovic and his Muslim allies in the collective presidency toward any negotiations based on the dissolution of Bosnia along ethnic lines. Mr. Izetbegovic and two other Muslims in the 10-member presidency have declined to attend the talks here, exposing a rift in Bosnia's leadership.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.S. Will Focus on Reducing Pesticides in Food Production
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Federal Government has decided to reduce the use of chemicals in the production of the nation's food, assigning a higher priority than in the past to protecting children's health and the environment.    If the change of policy is fully carried out, it could alter everything about the way food is grown and what Americans eat. It was announced Friday by the Environmental Protection Agency, the Food and Drug Administration and the Department of Agriculture and will be reinforced in a scientific report to be issued Tuesday.

nytimes_articles.headline: Your Home: Co-op Bargains; A Gamble That Can Pay Off
nytimes_articles.abstract: THIS may be the perfect summer to pick up a co-op apartment in the New York City area at a bargain price -- provided you are a contrarian thinker willing to take a gamble. For it's hardly a secret that co-ops have grown increasingly unpopular and unsalable of late.   One reason is financial. Banks will no longer lend money to buy certain co-op units, citing higher-than-normal risks. This is a result of the wave of sponsor defaults that swept the co-op industry in the last five years, leaving dozens of co-op corporations with cash-flow problems.

nytimes_articles.headline: Wilfredo Sauri Garcia and Nicole King
nytimes_articles.abstract: Nicole Roberta King, a daughter of Ina H. and Robert F. King of New York, was married yesterday to Wilfredo Sauri Garcia, a son of Juanita Garcia and Wilfredo Sauri of Rio Piedras, P.R. The Rev. Renee Hill, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Union Theological Seminary in New York.   Ms. King, who is 29, is keeping her name. She graduated from Princeton University and received a master's degree in English from the University of Pennsylvania, where she a Ph.D. candidate in English. She is to join the English department at the University of Maryland at College Park in September as an assistant professor of English.

nytimes_articles.headline:
Westchester Q&A;: Kara M. Fireman;
The Future of Girls' High School Sports
nytimes_articles.abstract:
THERE was a time, not so long ago, when even girls didn't take girls' competitive sports very seriously. It was better to be a cheerleader than a slugger, a twirler than a goalie. 

Boys' high school sports still attract far more attention than girls' sports. But things are changing. College athletic scouts are showing up at girls' varsity softball games. And some young women say that losing a big game is something they will always remember.

nytimes_articles.abstract: ECLIPSE FEVER By Walter Abish. 335 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $23.

nytimes_articles.headline: Moths To the Flame
nytimes_articles.abstract: A FEW minutes before Monday night's premiere of "Sleepless in Seattle" at the Loews Fine Arts Cinema, the skies opened up with a brief, hair-flattening rain. But somehow, as if by miracle or destiny, it tapered down to a reasonable drizzle as the stars arrived.   And how they arrived. They arrived as if from the skies, stepping out of black storm clouds of limousines onto the red carpeting on West 58th Street and past the barricaded mob of photographers who were so overcharged by the electricity from the storm that anything seemed possible.

nytimes_articles.headline: Shift Recommended In H.I.V. Treatment
nytimes_articles.abstract: An independent panel of experts appointed by the Government has suggested a major change in the strategy for treating people infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS. The experts said a widely used drug, AZT, was no longer necessarily recommended for patients with stable conditions and high enough counts of certain immune cells in their blood.

nytimes_articles.headline: Wickman Runs Out Of Luck in Yank Loss
nytimes_articles.abstract: They are talking about something called Orioles magic. In the streets. In the bars. In the dugout. Maybe it sounds corny, but the superb results make the talk difficult to dispute. The Orioles actually defeated the unbeatable Bob Wickman tonight. How much more magical can a team get?   Wickman, the fortunate Yankee pitcher who had won 11 straight games and had lost only once in his major league career, was confronted with the most magical team in baseball tonight.

nytimes_articles.headline: Mallory L. Israel, Bruce A. Huberman
nytimes_articles.abstract: Mr. and Mrs. Norman Israel of Short Hills, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Mallory Lewis Israel to Dr. Bruce Adam Huberman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Huberman of South Orange, N.J. An October wedding is planned.   Ms. Israel, 27, is a publicity coordinator at Donna Karan New York. She is a graduate of Arizona State University.

nytimes_articles.headline: Polo Benefit Today For Bosnian Children
nytimes_articles.abstract: TODAY at 3 P.M., the grounds of the Marshall Field estate in Huntington, now Caumsett State Park, will be the setting for a benefit polo match in what appears to be a resurgence of polo on Long Island.   The Long Island chapter of Save the Children, the child-care agency, will raise money to deliver aid, reunite families and continue education for children whose lives have been torn by the war in Bosnia and Herzegovina, said Susan Lassen of Cold Spring Harbor, founder and past president of the chapter.

nytimes_articles.headline: What's All the Fuss About Children's Book?
nytimes_articles.abstract: As a published children's-book illustrator, conscientious parent of two elementary-school children, a frequent workshop moderator at elementary schools throughout Suffolk County with the New York State Arts-in-Education Services and as former chairperson of our Southampton Elementary School's annual Authors and Illustrators Night, I read with bemused interest "Authors' Day Cancellation Ignites Furor at Sag Harbor School  [ May 30 ]  about Jim and Kate McMullen's new book, "The Noisy Giants Tea Party."   I had the pleasure of inviting the McMullens and their new book to this year's event at my children's school. Mr. McMullen was a gracious guest (his wife was unable to attend due to a prior commitment), signing books and conversing in his quiet, attentive manner with the many children who stopped at his table throughout the evening. My son (an aspiring artist himself!) asked to buy "The Noisy Giants," which we did, and it stayed at his bedside for many nights afterward, to be thumbed through again and again in wonder and delight.

nytimes_articles.headline: Youngster at Trigger Of Machine Gun
nytimes_articles.abstract: What could you have been thinking of when you ran the photo of the small boy trying out a machine gun?  [ Long Island Journal, June 13 ] . How exciting it must have been for him to have the opportunity to get behind a real machine gun. The next step is getting behind a real gun, and using it.   Anyone who has ever been a child, or the parent of one, knows the lifelong effect of early experiences on children. What will be the future dream of the little boy who got his picture in the paper or of the thousands of others who see it?

Hellman of Lloyd Harbor, L.I. Melvin Meacham, a justice of the peace from East Windsor, Conn., performed the ceremony at Avon Old Farms School in Avon, Conn. She graduated from Trinity College in Hartford and received a master's degree in computer science from Boston University. Her father is the vice president of engineering at Locknetics Security Engineering, an engineering company in Forestville, Conn. Her mother, Sima Frolov, is an engineer at the Northeast Utilities Service Company in Berlin, Conn.

nytimes_articles.headline: 'Power Lunches' in a Converted Barn
nytimes_articles.abstract: NEAR the intersection of Route 24 and Columbia Turnpike, where cows once grazed on rolling farmland, gleaming office parks rise from landscaped lawns. Only a weathered brick barn appears untouched by the development.   But close inspection reveals that it, too, is part of the change. This "historic barn," as a bold-lettered sign explains, is the unlikely home of a new organization called the Park Avenue Foundation and Club.

nytimes_articles.headline: Kathleen Fritsch, Rick Giannasi
nytimes_articles.abstract: Kathleen Fritsch, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. August Fritsch of Royal Oak, Mich., was married yesterday to Rick Giannasi, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Piero Giannasi of Fort Lee, N.J. The Rev. Edgar da Cunha, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Nicholas Church in Palisades Park, N.J.

nytimes_articles.headline: Kate Stookey, Samuel Haviland Jr.
nytimes_articles.abstract: Kate Worthington Stookey, a daughter of Lee and Byron Stookey of Brooklyn Heights, was married yesterday to Samuel St. John Haviland Jr., a son of Frances and Samuel Haviland of Farmington, Conn. The Rev. Alastair Votaw performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport, Conn.   Mrs. Haviland, 28, is a teacher of a bilingual sixth grade class at Public School 154 in the Bronx. She graduated magna cum laude from Temple University. Her father is a social studies teacher at the Manhattan Center for Science and Mathematics. Her mother teaches English as a second language at the Riverside Adult Learning Center in Manhattan.

nytimes_articles.headline: Hamlin Takes a 3-Shot Lead Over Daniel in Classic
nytimes_articles.abstract: It would have been easy for Shelley Hamlin to collapse after making bogeys on the first two holes in today's second round of the $450,000 L.P.G.A Classic.   Instead, the 44-year-old Hamlin displayed her resiliency by rallying for six birdies. Hamlin finished with a four-under-par 67 on a windy afternoon at the Greate Bay Country Club, matching her opening-day 67 for a 134 total. She finished the day with a three-shot lead over Beth Daniel, who also shot 67 after shooting 70 opening day.

nytimes_articles.abstract:
MUSIC AND FIREWORKS

The blast of horns and the boom of drums, sometimes complemented by the blast and boom of fireworks in the sky, will herald Independence Day at concerts throughout the state. 

The United States Military Academy Concert Band, the largest component of the Academy Band, will play at 7:30 P.M. Friday at Brookdale Park in Bloomfield and Montclair. The grand finale of the evening will be a ground and aerial fireworks display.

nytimes_articles.headline: Honolulu Drivers Find Traffic Jam in Paradise
nytimes_articles.abstract: Hawaii, the land of seemingly endless tranquil beaches, has become, around this city at least, a land of seemingly endless traffic jams.   The roads in and around Honolulu have become so snarled that the Federal Government is offering more than $700 million to help build a light-rail system that would link the downtown with growing areas west of the city.

nytimes_articles.headline: Nancy Anne Low, James Sullivan
nytimes_articles.abstract: Nancy Anne Low, a daughter of Mary R. Low of Potomac, Md., and the late George M. Low, was married yesterday to James McGrath Sullivan, a son of Barbara M. Sullivan of Bedford, N.Y., and the late Edward O. Sullivan Jr. Msgr. Thomas Gartland performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Church in Bedford.   Mrs. Sullivan is the manager of training and development at Estee Lauder Inc. in New York. She graduated from Mount Vernon College. Her father was a deputy administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration in Washington and president of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute.

nytimes_articles.abstract: DEAR Anthony Young:   You were wearing a white T-shirt with shiny blue lettering that grumbled, "If I Had Any Luck It'd Be All Bad." You had been the losing pitcher. Again. In the Mets' box score an "L" was next to your name for the 23d consecutive time, tying a major league record that one Cliff Curtis set in 1911.

nytimes_articles.headline: RESULTS PLUS
nytimes_articles.abstract: GOLF Pavin Hangs On for a One-Shot Lead  Corey Pavin put a bunker shot to within six feet on the 18th hole to avoid squandering a three-stroke lead for a second time yesterday and take a one-stroke advantage into the final round of the Greater Hartford Open in Cromwell, Conn. With wind gusting to 20 miles per hour, Pavin double-bogeyed the 17th hole after a chip shot from a ravine got caught on the fringe. After narrowly missing a 15-foot putt, he missed a 3-footer coming back. "It was the kind of day where everything went haywire," Pavin said.

nytimes_articles.headline: New Woes For Polio Survivors
nytimes_articles.abstract:
JUDIE DINANNO remembers little of the three months in 1958 when she was hospitalized for polio at the age of 18. She recovered fully. But several years ago, polio once again cast its shadow over her life.

"I used to walk for miles and miles," said Mrs. Dinanno, a resident of Norwood. "And there came a time when I couldn't get around the block without this awful pain in my hips and thighs. I couldn't understand what was happening to me, so I just stopped walking rather than question it."

nytimes_articles.headline: Saving and Trade
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   "Trade Sanity With Japan" (editorial, June 16) falls back on an old shibboleth of free traders: "Longstanding trade deficits reflect insufficient saving." There is a good argument for free trade, but that is not it.

nytimes_articles.headline: In Miami, Talk of Talking With Cuba
nytimes_articles.abstract: Emboldened by the change of administrations in Washington and deteriorating economic conditions in Cuba, new voices calling for a more flexible attitude toward Fidel Castro's Communist Government are emerging in the Cuban exile community here and challenging the hegemony of established groups.   The resulting political ferment most threatens the Cuban-American National Foundation, which for a dozen years has dominated, if not monopolized, exile politics. Having identified itself with the Reagan and Bush Administrations, the group has, in recent months, seen its influence diminish in Washington and had its political agenda increasingly questioned here.

nytimes_articles.headline: Diplomats Are Wary on Eve of Haitian Showdown
nytimes_articles.abstract: As Haiti's ousted President prepared for talks in New York with the army commander who overthrew him, diplomats predicted today that the meeting would quickly disclose whether the country's military was willing to relinquish power in Haiti.   The talks on Sunday between the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, Haiti's first democratically elected President, and Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras are to focus on issues like forming a new Government and the mandate of an international police force to be sent to the country to guard against human rights violations. It is the first meeting between the two enemies since September 1991, when a military coup forced Father Aristide into exile.

nytimes_articles.headline: Public & Private; Another Kind of Closet
nytimes_articles.abstract: Sometime in the next few weeks the President will decide whether or not to lift the ban on gay men and lesbians in the military. Faced with considerable opposition in Congress, it looks today as though he is likely to settle for a compromise that is politically safe. But it also looks as though that compromise is un-American.    The new policy for allowing gay people to serve in the armed forces -- as they have done since this country was founded -- is known in shorthand as "Don't ask, don't tell." This gives the illusion that sexuality in the service will become a private matter.  Illusory it is. Several of the proposed compromises would replace the outright ban on gay soldiers with the creation of a permanent cadre of second-class military men and women.

nytimes_articles.headline: Fourstardave Aces Poker Stakes
nytimes_articles.abstract: Fourstardave, the remarkable senior citizen of the turf, showed that he still had plenty of zip at the ripe old age of 8 when he won the Poker Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday and even broke the record for the race that he had set four years ago.   The venerable gelding, who is trained by Leo O'Brien, stalked Blare of Trumpets most of the way under a firm ride by Richard Migliore. He took the lead entering the homestretch and then was challenged by the 7-5 favorite, Adam Smith, the British horse, who had won his last four starts. But at the wire, Fourstardave was widening his lead to three and a half lengths over Adam Smith, who was clinging to second place by a neck over Lech.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Grand Hotel, But Not What You'd Call Homey
nytimes_articles.abstract: "Rather chilly, don't you think?" said a friend I encountered the other day in the lobby of the new Four Seasons Hotel on East 57th Street in Manhattan. And indeed, the scuttlebutt about this I. M. Pei-designed tower, surely the most talked-about new hotel in New York in years, is that all this limestone and onyx and Danish beechwood paneling has yielded a building that, besides being terribly expensive (reportedly $1 million a room), is about as far from warm and cuddly as a hotel can get.    Well, yes. The Four Seasons is anything but the model of Hotel as Teddy Bear. But even though Mr. Pei and his associate architect, Frank Williams, do disdain the current taste for intimate, boutiquey hotels, I would not write off the Four Seasons so quickly. For this 52-story building harks back to the great hotels of New York's past, to the romantic towers of the 1920's and 30's that are still the defining presence of the skyline. The real ancestor of this building is not the rest of Mr. Pei's work but the Waldorf-Astoria.

nytimes_articles.headline: POSTINGS: Broadway and 79th; Filene's Basement Coming
nytimes_articles.abstract: A well-known though fictional Manhattanite, Artur Sammler of Saul Bellow's 1970 novel, "Mr. Sammler's Planet," would walk the Upper West Side habitually pursuing "esthetic consumption of the environment." These days, neighborhood pedestrians are more likely to practice conspicuous consumption of the merchandise. And that opportunity is certain to increase in November, when Filene's Basement opens its first Manhattan store, at the northeast corner of Broadway and 79th Street.   The brand-name and designer-fashion off-price retailer will take over both floors and the basement at 2220-6 Broadway, a total of 32,000 square feet. The building formerly housed an outlet of the now defunct Lionel Kiddie City Toys. "When I saw Kiddie City was going out I thought it was a natural for Filene's Basement," said Robert H. Gibson of Helmsley Spear, who represented the 52-store chain in the deal. "And when I got their people to come down, they felt the same way."

nytimes_articles.headline: The Most Entertaining Americans? Canadians
nytimes_articles.abstract: WHAT'S SO FUNNY ABOUT Canada? It's a big country with a lot of snow, Mounties and politely boring people who say "eh." The British novelist Kingsley Amis put a fictitious tome titled "Canadian Wit and Humor" on his list of the World's Shortest Books. "Worthwhile Canadian Initiative" was the winner of The New Republic magazine's Most Boring Headline contest.    Joke-wise, Canada gets no respect. But it should, especially since Canada has produced some of America's funniest comedians, actors, writers, directors -- a veritable army of renegade humor professionals. Without them, there would have been no "Saturday Night Live," no "SCTV," no Spy magazine, no "Ghostbusters," no "Wayne's World," no sidekick for David Letterman to take with him to CBS. Expatriate Canucks like Dan Aykroyd, Michael J. Fox, Mike Myers, Phil Hartman, John Candy, Rick Moranis and Martin Short could gather on Thursday to celebrate Canada Day, a holiday most Americans would rank somewhere below National Pickle Week.

nytimes_articles.headline: But How Did Fermat Do It?
nytimes_articles.abstract: So now another bold mathematician thinks he has proved Fermat's last theorem, the most notorious mathematical puzzle of all time. And some of the world's leading mathematicians think he just might have done it. But one would be wise to wait just a bit before declaring victory. Proving this theorem has frustrated the best mathematical minds for more than three and a half centuries; several previous claims withered away under intense scrutiny.   The theorem itself is deceptively simple. Every student is taught in geometry the old formula for linking the square of the hypotenuse of a right triangle with the squares of the other two sides, namely a  + b  = c . But Pierre de Fermat, a 17th century French mathematician, had the insight that the formula would not work for any higher powers. There are no positive whole numbers that will fit the equation a  + b  = c  , or any such formula raised to even higher powers.

nytimes_articles.headline:
The Deadly Sins/Gluttony;
Remembering Mr. Pinkerton
nytimes_articles.abstract:
A FEW of us meet now and again, not often these days, in the Gran Paradiso or the Cafe Pelican. Once it was downstairs at Bianchi's, but like so much of London, Bianchi's isn't there anymore.

We're of an age now, no longer young yet not entirely old, eating less than we did, drinking a bit less too, though not by much. We have the past in common, and by chance were once clients of Mr. Pinkerton, an accountant who was passed among us in the 1960's, recommended as a miracle worker. In the Gran Paradiso or the Cafe Pelican, we invariably end up talking about Mr. Pinkerton -- about his small idiosyncrasies, and the ways in which he was different from accountants we have subsequently known. We touch upon the subject of gluttony, since it was gluttony that destroyed him, or so we have always assumed. We wonder about its nature and the form it takes, and if St. Thomas Aquinas was fair to designate it a sin when more charitably it might perhaps have been called an eating disorder. We recall other instances of its excesses and other gluttons we have encountered.

nytimes_articles.headline: Clinton Administration Has No Plans to Arrest Sheik Now
nytimes_articles.abstract: With the help of a confidential informer operating inside a suspected bombing ring, Federal agents recorded many private conversations of Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman, the fiery Egyptian cleric who has been blamed for inspiring terrorism in Egypt and the United States. But after reviewing those recordings the Clinton Administration does not plan for now to arrest Mr. Abdel Rahman, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.   The decision comes as law-enforcement and Administration officials debate how to proceed with Mr. Abdel Rahman. Senior officials in New York and Washington said the tapes did not reveal enough information to justify an arrest. But others said enough evidence could have been marshaled, but there was a desire to allow Mr. Abdel Rahman to remain free because the Government gains important intelligence about Muslim radicals by watching the people attracted to him as he works from his mosque in Jersey City.

nytimes_articles.abstract: McGuire Air Force Base, the military enterprise that sustains this region, went from the brink of extinction this week to an expanded role that seems to assure a prosperous future for its neighboring communities into the next century.   Not only will McGuire be kept open as an active Air Force base, contrary to a Pentagon recommendation in March, but it will expand in size and stature as the chief air mobility wing for the eastern United States, the Base Closing and Realignment Commission decided on Thursday.

nytimes_articles.abstract: As revelations of mismanagement at Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield continue, Republicans here have rushed to hang the issue around the neck of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.   In news releases and interviews, they have heaped blame on the Governor's appointee, the superintendent of the State Insurance Department, Salvatore R. Curiale. nytimes_articles.headline: New Approaches To Menopause
nytimes_articles.abstract: "Menopause: New Research and Treatment"  [ June 6 ]  was well written with a lot of good information. Unfortunately, I feel that it misrepresented some of the effects of exercise on the woman with osteoporosis and might be misleading to the general public. It is important to make a distinction between the woman who has osteoporosis and the woman who does not, and what is appropriate therapy for each of these two very different groups. In the population that does not have osteoporosis, proper medical, dietary and physical activity can be preventative measures taken by an individual. In the population with osteoporosis, the progression of the disease may be slowed down with this intervention, but not "reversed."   The picture accompanying the article was taken of a class of woman who have osteoporosis. They are exercising to maintain their present medical status, not "prevent" the disease. As a physical therapist I believe that weight-bearing exercises such as walking and specially designed exercises are essential components in an exercise program. I feel, however, that aerobics and jogging are too vigorous with their high-impact features for this fragile-bone population and are not recommended by our staff.

nytimes_articles.headline: Yankee Fans Stay Away, But Bronx Isn't Why
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Only George Steinbrenner could blame the Bronx for withering Yankee Stadium attendance (news article, June 18). Over a decade, the Yankees' owner devastated an organization that was rebuilt only in his absence. He made a generation of fans pay to watch games on television. And through it all, he raised ticket prices. Now he blames parking problems and a bad neighborhood for lagging attendance. Is that why Yogi Berra and his friends still refuse to set foot in the stadium? MATT BAI  New York, June 18, 1993

nytimes_articles.headline: 'Life's Dominion'
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Laurence H. Tribe's review of "Life's Dominion," while chiding the author for begging a "key question" regarding a secular state's power to protect particular people, itself begs the big abortion question by describing fetuses as "helpless creatures that are on their way to becoming such people." "Becoming" implies "not arrived," which logically precludes the early fetuses from being people. Mr. Tribe has served them up to the defenders of abortion as nonpeople and thereby, in one answer-assuming stroke, really eliminated most, if not all, of the arguments against abortion.  WILLIAM H. IZLAR JR. Atlanta

nytimes_articles.headline: One Campaign by Alter: Many Interpretations
nytimes_articles.abstract: On a recent Sunday morning, the Rev. Clarence A. Norman Sr. faced the members of his church -- one of the largest black congregations in Brooklyn -- and introduced his choice for Public Advocate. "I'm not telling you what to do," said the minister, ending a somewhat tepid endorsement of Susan D. Alter, who is running for the post that is replacing the job of City Council President. "But I consider her a friend."   As Ms. Alter stood at the pulpit, praising the minister "for his courage," many in the congregation seemed impressed with the white, red-haired woman who talked with passion about "the brotherhood of man." But some were not, notably the pastor's son, Clarence A. Norman Jr., the state Assemblyman and Brooklyn Democratic leader who sat fuming at the sight of the woman who had crossed party lines in an alliance with Republican mayoral candidate, Rudolph W. Giuliani.
