nytimes_articles.headline:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
The Subject Was Horses
nytimes_articles.abstract: In what he called a "world of 20th-century agitation," the Italian artist Marino Marini created some 400 sculptures, changing "the form and expression of my work" while feeling "no need to change the subject." MARINO MARINI: The Sculpture (Abrams, $75) manages an overview of his 60-year career. In the horse and rider, Marini (1901-80) sensed "the whole story of humanity and nature at all times." Unlike traditional representations of striding steeds and heroic generals, Marini's work depicted toil and tragedy. "My aim is to render palpable the last stages in the dissolution of a myth, the myth of the heroic and victorious individual," the artist once wrote. Likewise, in portraiture, Marini attempted to create "human documents, stripped of all historical pathos." Sam Hunter, a professor of art and archeology at Princeton University, provides a broad overview of Marini's work, reflecting on its Roman and Etruscan influences and on his apprenticeship with the sculptors Arturo Martini and Medardo Rosso. The photographer David Finn has taken several shots of each piece, lingering over them as a visitor's eye might, coming closer to describe a texture, stepping back to appreciate a certain balance. Mr. Hunter appreciates that there is no better articulation of Marini's intentions than the artist's own words, and they are quoted at length, showing the humility and grace of Marini's apocalyptic vision: "If the whole earth is destroyed in our atomic age, I feel that the human forms which may survive as mere fossils will have become sculptures similar to mine."

nytimes_articles.headline: Fugitive Somali Warlord's Rivals Joust for Power
nytimes_articles.abstract: Since the United Nations unleashed its military campaign against a powerful Somali clan leader, dozens of other factional chiefs have been jockeying for power and pledging cooperation with the peacekeepers in the hope of dominating Somalia's political transition, United Nations and Western officials say.   While officials say the move against Gen. Mohammed Farah Aidid's arsenals and fighters was unavoidable, some lament that it has set back the timetable for creating a Somali government after two years of anarchy. By issuing an arrest warrant that sent General Aidid into hiding, some say, the United Nations inadvertently added to the instability threatening relief efforts and reconstruction.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Rural Plateau and Its Earthy Cuisine
nytimes_articles.abstract: I DISCOVERED Puglia about 15 years ago while seeking a route from Rome to Greece. There had to be an alternative to the long, boring train ride to the Brindisi ferry; there had at least to be something to see on the way. The logical place to begin looking was the region to which the port of Brindisi belongs, Puglia.   As an archeology student, I knew a few things about the area: that the modern region of Puglia corresponds to ancient Apulia plus ancient Calabria, which has nothing to do with modern Calabria; that there were pre-Greek people called Apuli, Peucetii and Messapii; that the museum of Taranto, the Spartan colony of Taras and later Roman Tarentum, was worth any amount of difficulty to see; that in 37 B.C. the Roman poet Horace had had any amount of difficulty getting to Brundisium, terminus of the Via Appia; and that Virgil had died there on his way back from Greece in 19 B.C. The modern version of the trip did not offer hope that the poets' experiences had been exceptional.

Rococo Setting for Classic Italian Fare
nytimes_articles.abstract:
NO vestige of the old Fox and Rider remains on this site. Instead, this roomy Colonial has been scrubbed, painted and polished to a gleam, inside and out, and now Giardino stands as one of the prettiest dining spots in this part of the county. A garden at the entrance and gorgeous fresh bouquets and bucolic murals within bear out handsomely the restaurant's name. nytimes_articles.headline: Reasons for Closing A Regional High School
nytimes_articles.abstract: The June 6 article concerning the closing of David Brearley Regional High School in Kenilworth ("This Town Will Die Without Our School") was noticeably curtailed in that it failed to discuss in complete terms the reasons and motivation that the Union County Regional High School District No. 1 Board of Education used in deciding to close the school. In fact, many of the important details pertaining to the Board of Education's point of view were omitted and should be addressed and clarified.   For example, the Kenilworth group opposing Brearley's closing is quoted as saying that the town alone could handle the operation of the school. On the contrary, it would be extremely difficult for Kenilworth to financially support the operation of Brearley alone in view of the high costs already facing the residents because of the judgment in the Waldorf case.

nytimes_articles.headline: Getting Into Buckingham
nytimes_articles.abstract: Buckingham Palace in London has announced that there will be 18 major rooms open to the public this August and September, the first time that visitors are being admitted to the palace in the five-year plan to raise money to repair burned-out Windsor Castle. The rooms include the Green, Blue and White Drawing Rooms, the Silk Tapestry Room, the East Gallery, the Music Room, the State Dining Room, the Throne Room and the Marble Hall. A high point of the tour will be the 155-foot-long Picture Gallery, which is hung with paintings by such masters as Rembrandt, Rubens and Van Dyck.   Travelers determined to get into the palace without waiting in line can obtain advance tickets through at least four tour companies that obtained allotments for group visits. The catch is that the tickets are being sold as part of packages that also include hotel accommodations and-or other sightseeing trips.

nytimes_articles.headline: Early Blueprints for Abstract Expressionism
nytimes_articles.abstract: Who is Augustus Vincent Tack? The name hovers tantalizingly in the background of the history of American painting, a vague presence in need of definition.    Tack, who died in 1949 at the age of 78, is probably best known as a visionary precursor of Abstract Expressionism, American painting's finest hour. The semi-abstract landscapes that he began painting in the late 1920's -- with their flat expanses of color flecked and faceted with contrasting tones -- look like blueprints for Clyfford Still's fissured abstractions. (This connection was emphasized when their work was placed in proximity in "The Natural Paradise: Painting in America 1800-1950," an exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art in 1976.)

nytimes_articles.headline: A Crossroads Of History on Italy's Heel
nytimes_articles.abstract:
ALONG the southeastern coast of Italy, a little more than a quarter of the way up the Italian boot, a spur of land juts into the Adriatic Sea, looking out across the clear blue-green waters that separate western Europe from the Byzantine east. It is a chalky limestone massif known as the Promontorio del Gargano, or Gargano Peninsula, and it offers many of the finest sandy bathing beaches, spectacular seaside vistas, and some of the most beautiful mountainous forests in the whole of Italy.

Yet the Gargano, situated in the northeast of the economically underdeveloped Apulia, has until recently been held in comparatively low esteem, except by budget-conscious Italian campers. The beneficial result of this is that the small villages along its 65 miles of coastline still retain their character and provincial charm. Best of all, prices for accommodations are less than half of what you would pay in other parts of Italy, generally an expensive place to visit.

I did it for my wife, who wanted a vacation in England, where we have a daughter thriving at malnutrition level as an actress. I am also a cheapskate. nytimes_articles.headline: The Call of a Lifetime
nytimes_articles.abstract: The phone call, he knew, could change his life. And it scared him. He had been told to expect the call at 3 o'clock last Friday afternoon.   The call was coming from the basketball coach at American University in Washington, and Ronnell Williams, age 18, did not want to miss it. He was the lean, 6-foot-6-inch leading scorer for Taft High School at 29 points a game and an honorable mention on the McDonald's all-America basketball team. nytimes_articles.headline: Lightning Protection: Focus on Small Jobs
nytimes_articles.abstract: ALTHOUGH lightning can occur in any season, summer storms generally produce the largest amount. Houses in urban and built-up suburban regions usually are at only a small risk, because lightning tends to strike just the highest points, like tall commercial buildings in such areas.   Not so in open places like parks, fields, farmland and beachfront property. In those areas, houses, trees and often people are frequently the highest points and, thus, the most likely targets.

nytimes_articles.headline: Gift Certificates
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor: I must express my disappointment at the Angel of the Sea Bed & Breakfast in Cape May, N.J. I was given a $300 gift certificate purchased there. When I went to use it a year later, the proprietor told me it had expired and would not accept it for payment. How does a gift certificate expire? I was shocked that the highly rated and often-mentioned Angel of the Sea would lower to such a policy.  MICHAEL A. KIEL Hawthorne, N.J.  Kathleen A. Davis, innkeeper, responds: Putting expiration dates on gift certificates is a fairly common business practice. We sell hundreds of certificates a year, and each purchaser is told. The one-year expiration date is printed clearly on the front of the card. We tried to explain our position to Mr. Kiel in person and tried to accommodate him by giving him part value for a certificate that had expired four months before, but this was not good enough.

nytimes_articles.headline:
BACKTALK;
The Sport of Kings, but Apparently Not of Politicians
nytimes_articles.abstract:
When Gov. Mario M. Cuomo appointed me to his new Advisory Commission on Racing in the 21st Century last summer, I temporarily suspended my longstanding belief that the political process was the problem and not the solution for horse racing in New York.

It turns out I was wrong ever to doubt my initial impression.

A year and a mountain of documents later, it is clearer to me than ever that politics is largely to blame for the sport's decline in New York. Worse, politics is now the odds-on favorite to thwart both the immediate and the long-term solutions that are racing's only chance for recovery.

nytimes_articles.headline: Experts Change Guides to Using Drugs for H.I.V.
nytimes_articles.abstract: An independent panel of experts created by the Government has recommended a major shift in the strategy for treating people infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS.   The new recommendations, issued Friday night after a three-day meeting at the National Institutes of Health, provide greater flexibility than the current ones. Although the new guidelines are not official Federal health policy, they are expected have a strong influence on doctors who care for patients with H.I.V. and AIDS.

nytimes_articles.headline: Europe Car Rental
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor: In addition to the issue of cost, raised in the article by John Brannon Albright ("Figuring the Cost of Car Rentals in Europe," May 9), there is a more important problem for those of us that are 70 years old or older. Most European car rental agencies, including branches of American companies, will not rent to a driver over 70.   My wife and I, both over 70 and both good drivers with exemplary records, had to make arrangements for rental here before we left for Ireland. I advised the travel agent that unless we had a guarantee of a car we would not make the trip. After some effort we had the guarantee and then spent almost a week driving around the country.

nytimes_articles.headline: Making Theater In Unlikely Places
nytimes_articles.abstract: The rusting piers near the Penn rail yards on the West Side of Manhattan may seem a million miles from classic, open-air Greek theater, but not anymore. En Garde Arts has taken care of that. The latest site-specific production by the nonprofit experimental group is "Orestes," an updating of the Euripides play by Charles L. Mee Jr.; it opens tonight near 59th Street and 12th Avenue, where Donald Trump is planning to build the Riverside South development. The Hudson River, the New Jersey skyline and the twisted spines of two large piers are all part of the background against which the tragedy will be enacted. Directed by Tina Landau, the work is the latest in a series by En Garde, which has been setting drama in unexpected places since 1985.    Anne Hamburger, En Garde's founder and producer, has said the group's mission is to "challenge the notion of the traditional well-made play" and to "create a theater that is visually exciting." Using dusk as its curtain, En Garde has presented works in Central Park and the meatpacking district, among other places. Indoor sites have included the Chelsea Hotel (for a second look at the punk rocker Sid Vicious and his girlfriend, Nancy Spungen) and the dilapidated Victory Theater on West 42d Street.

nytimes_articles.headline: Church Burglary On Rise
nytimes_articles.abstract: BURGLARIES in churches, synagogues and mosques around the state are on the rise, law-enforcement officials say.   "Thieves are ripping off churches more and more these days," said Detective Capt. James Buckley of the Paterson Police Department. "Years ago there was a certain amount of honor even among thieves. You would never catch anyone burglarizing a church or a synagogue. Now it's par for the course."

nytimes_articles.headline: A Therapeutic Program for Troubled Students
nytimes_articles.abstract: DURING the final weeks of the spring term, most high school teachers have to struggle to capture their students' interest. So it was to be expected that some of the teen-agers in Sam Hedrick's world-cultures history class were gazing into space recently instead of their textbooks.  Still, Mr. Hedrick managed to steer a conversation about welfare abuse into a spirited discussion of World War II and the rise of Hitler.   Despite these trappings of a conventional high school classroom, which has such standard social studies features as world maps, globes and computers, this class actually took place inside the Psychiatric Institute of the Westchester County Medical Center in Valhalla. And the students, who have had problems with alcohol and drug abuse, as well as psychiatric disorders that include anxiety, depression, suicide attempts and severe mood swings, are enrolled in West-Prep. Checking to Avoid Relapses    The program, a joint effort of the Westchester County Medical Center, New York Medical College and the Board of Cooperative Educational Services of Southern Westchester, offers troubled adolescents a combination of school and therapeutic treatment on an outpatient basis.

nytimes_articles.headline:
Focus: Rio Rancho, N.M.;
Atop a Mesa, a City Just Grows and Grows
nytimes_articles.abstract:
FIFTEEN years ago, this mesa-top community 18 miles northwest of downtown Albuquerque seemed destined for the obscurity of just another desert town, albeit one with a touch of scandal to its history. Four officials of the company that developed it had been convicted of fleecing retirees in a land scam.

But Rio Rancho, on the Rio Grande in central New Mexico, has become something of a Cinderella. It has been adding manufacturing jobs and population, making it the envy of job-hungry cities across the country. Its population grew by more than 239 percent from 1980 to 1990, making Rio Rancho -- now with 37,000 residents -- the fastest growing "small city" in the nation, according to the magazine American Demographics.

nytimes_articles.headline: Gretzky Is Taking Action Against Nike
nytimes_articles.abstract: WAYNE GRETZKY is suing Nike Inc. for $6 million, alleging that the company reneged on a deal for him to endorse a denim clothing line after he became sidelined with a back injury. Gretzky seeks $1 million in compensatory damages and $5 million in exemplary damages.   The Los Angeles Kings star alleges that his deal "obligated Nike, among other things, to make Gretzky an integral part of its denim-apparel marketing."

nytimes_articles.headline: YELTSIN PRESSING TALKS ON CHARTER
nytimes_articles.abstract: President Boris N. Yeltsin sent Russia's constitutional conference back for a third round of work today, confirming that major differences remained between Moscow and the outlying regions over the basic political shape of a proposed federation.   Speaking briefly at a full session of the 700 delegates, Mr. Yeltsin declared that the "intensive work" of the conference had succeeded in crafting a single draft from competing documents and innumerable proposals.

nytimes_articles.headline: Neuchatel
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor: Paul Hofmann's charming article on Neuchatel brought back many pleasant memories of my two years as a graduate student at the University of Neuchatel. He was remiss, however, in not mentioning the beautiful views of lakes and Alps and walks through pastureland and pine forests at Chaumont, high above Neuchatel in the Jura Mountains, which is easily reached from the center of town by bus and then funicular at La Coudre.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Wealth of Wright Designs Is Dispersed
nytimes_articles.abstract: THROUGHOUT THE 1980'S, Thomas S. Monaghan, the founder, owner and chairman of Domino's Pizza, often paid huge prices for designs by Frank Lloyd Wright. And, for a time, Domino's corporate collection was the most comprehensive assemblage of Wright's decorative arts in the world.    But in the 1990's, the financially troubled Domino's began selling portions of the collection, which consisted of 300 architectural furnishings and scores of drawings, to reduce its debt. Mr. Monaghan no longer talks about his passionate interest in Frank Lloyd Wright. After a year of private sales and a major auction earlier this month, most of the collection, which cost about $13 million, has been sold. Domino's still owns a score of leaded-glass windows, a dozen pieces of furniture and an archive of drawings and other papers -- but the rest is gone.

nytimes_articles.headline: An Eastern Canyon
nytimes_articles.abstract: MANY of us, in our enthusiasm for exotic foreign travel, tend to overlook the native wonders in our own backyard. Nowhere is this more true than in the Eastern part of the country, where pristine wilderness gave way to industrialization and deforestation long ago. But in many of these areas the forests have grown back and industry has moved on, leaving quiet, unnoticed regions ripe for rediscovery.   I happened upon such a surprise last year on a weekend canoe trip with a group of neighbors from Washington, D.C. One of them had arranged for a two-day trip on Pine Creek in north-central Pennsylvania, about a six-hour drive from Washington and an equal distance from New York City.

ART;
Across 100 Years, Through L.I. Collectors' Eyes
nytimes_articles.abstract:
AMONG Long Island's many valuable resources are a significant number of important art collectors, many of whom are generous lenders and donors to museums. Without the benefactions of Samuel Parrish, August Heckscher, Mary Woodhouse, William K. Vanderbilt and other patrons, the region would not have the museums that now display their treasures.

Recognizing that fact, and in the hope of future donations and bequests, museums everywhere regularly call on collectors to contribute to temporary exhibitions like "Long Island Collections: The Gilded Age to the 1990's," the show at the Nassau County Museum of Art in Roslyn Harbor.

nytimes_articles.headline:
The Deadly Sins/Gluttony;
Remembering Mr. Pinkerton
nytimes_articles.abstract:
A FEW of us meet now and again, not often these days, in the Gran Paradiso or the Cafe Pelican. Once it was downstairs at Bianchi's, but like so much of London, Bianchi's isn't there anymore.

We're of an age now, no longer young yet not entirely old, eating less than we did, drinking a bit less too, though not by much. We have the past in common, and by chance were once clients of Mr. Pinkerton, an accountant who was passed among us in the 1960's, recommended as a miracle worker. In the Gran Paradiso or the Cafe Pelican, we invariably end up talking about Mr. Pinkerton -- about his small idiosyncrasies, and the ways in which he was different from accountants we have subsequently known. We touch upon the subject of gluttony, since it was gluttony that destroyed him, or so we have always assumed. We wonder about its nature and the form it takes, and if St. Thomas Aquinas was fair to designate it a sin when more charitably it might perhaps have been called an eating disorder. We recall other instances of its excesses and other gluttons we have encountered.

nytimes_articles.headline: Sampling Seafood in the Norwegian Style
nytimes_articles.abstract: ONE might think that since Connecticut borders the water, good seafood restaurants would be a dime a dozen. But one of the most frequently asked questions of a restaurant reviewer is "Where can I get fresh, well-prepared seafood?"   We have a ready answer: Fjord Fisheries in Stamford. The small, appealingly decorated place is in a sports complex just off Interstate 95 at Exit 6. To frequent diners-out, the space might look familiar as the site of several past restaurants, Oslo being the most recent.

nytimes_articles.headline: Jamaica: Prosperous Isle in Queens
nytimes_articles.abstract: When Ken Bernard and his two partners decided recently to open an upscale bistro offering Caribbean and other dishes and sidewalk dining, they looked past obvious spots like TriBeCa, SoHo or the Upper West Side.   Instead, they invested about $270,000 in a vacant storefront in downtown Jamaica, a commercial hub in southeastern Queens that not long ago had deteriorated amid the urban decline that ravaged other commercial districts in New York City and across the nation.

nytimes_articles.headline: 53 Youths Are Selected By General Foods U.S.A.
nytimes_articles.abstract: "I'M sorry to say I'm happy to get a rejection letter," said Michael E. Aquilino, a marketing major at Iona College in New Rochelle who has sent his resume for a summer job to 46 companies. Mr. Aquilino, a senior who began contacting companies in February, has so far received rejection letters from only 5 of them.   "The most promising rejection came from Xerox in Stamford," he reported. "It said that they had nothing part-time but to contact them when I was ready for full-time employment. That cheered me. Maybe they saw something they liked in my resume. But I can't help wondering if the other companies even opened my resume. They must be getting thousands. I feel I'm in competition with the whole world this summer."

nytimes_articles.headline: Tackling Costs Of Sharing At Libraries
nytimes_articles.abstract:
THE Scarsdale Library, like the 38 other public libraries in the county, is a quiet, unassuming cornerstone of its community. People of all ages use its books, periodicals, tapes, compact disks, large-print books and CD-ROM's and other computer technology. They flock to its meeting rooms for story time, concerts, film series, poetry readings, lectures and art exhibits.

Patrons can relax on upholstered chairs in the wood-paneled reading room and gaze at the pastoral grounds or isolate themselves in one of three private study rooms. Librarians seem eager to help.

nytimes_articles.headline: Mexico Eases The Way for U.S. Motorists
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Mexican Government and the American Automobile Association have announced a program that will allow motorists from the United States to enter Mexico more easily by getting their tourist cards and temporary automobile permits from A.A.A.-affiliated clubs in the border states. Motorists will also be able to use their credit cards to post the bond required, based on the value of their car, through the A.A.A. Previously this paperwork had to be processed at border crossings; the new system is designed to overcome traffic tie-ups.    The program will go into effect on July 1 and will be available to both members and nonmembers of the A.A.A. in Texas, New Mexico and Arizona, and only to members in California.

nytimes_articles.headline: Islanders Pick Name With a Ring to It
nytimes_articles.abstract: Does the name Bertuzzi sound familiar to Rangers fans? It should. Larry Bertuzzi was the arbitrator who last summer ruled that Eric Lindros had been traded by Quebec to the Philadelphia Flyers instead of the Rangers.   Another Bertuzzi might soon torment the Rangers. He is Todd Bertuzzi, a grandnephew of the arbitrator, who was chosen today by the Islanders as their first choice in the National Hockey League entry draft.

nytimes_articles.headline: Neuchatel
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor: The three automates in your story, "Enchantments of a Swiss Town" by Paul Hofmann (April 18), have a cousin in the States. An automaton built in London in 1810 by another Swiss clockmaker, Henri Maillardet, is the pride and joy of the Franklin Institute Science Museum in Philadelphia.   Our automaton is also the size of a 3-to-4-year-old boy. He combines the talents of the Scribe and Draftsman described in your article about Neuchatel. His repertoire includes four drawings and three poems (in French and English), all stored in his brass memory. The lifelike movements of the puppet are activated by a complex combination of wind-up motors, cams and levers in an ornate chest that forms the automaton's base.

nytimes_articles.headline: Residents Pursue the State's Identity
nytimes_articles.abstract:
DO Connecticut residents see themselves as members of a community or merely a group of individuals? Is there a Connecticut identity? The Connecticut Humanities Council and the Connecticut Museum Association took up those questions last week in the hope that the discussion might help residents address the challenges facing the entire state. Naturally, there was no definitive agreement on an answer. 

At a daylong conference, called "Conceiving Connecticut: Character, Identity and Sense of Place in the Land of Steady Habits," more than 100 participants including educators, historians, museum professionals, public officials and businesspeople gathered at the Yale University Art Gallery in New Haven on Monday to attempt to define common traditions and values.

nytimes_articles.headline: Dashed Hopes: When Tour Companies Go Under
nytimes_articles.abstract: EARLIER this month, Milestone Educational Institute of Cambridge, Mass., a commercial tour operator, abruptly shut its doors, leaving an estimated 5,000 students and teachers without the tickets to Europe or hotel vouchers they paid for long ago. The Massachusetts Attorney General said complaints received immediately from schools in 27 states involving 1,160 would-be travelers showed the school groups had lost $2.4 million. When all the complaints are gathered authorities expect a total above $6.5 million.    Massachusetts has moved against Milestone and its owner, Christopher DuMello Kenyon, who was served with lawsuit papers in England in mid-June, according to Leslie Davies, an assistant Attorney General. The state got a restraining order to keep Mr. Kenyon from again selling travel arrangements in Massachusetts and sued for refunds to clients, plus civil penalties and costs.

In "Alone at the Beach," Chris and Lonnie and Robbie and Alex and Molly, all summer shares, show up at a house in the Hamptons. "Urban escapees" all, they answered the ad of George, the owner, and gained instant acceptance long distance. No screening. No strings. Trust chance.

nytimes_articles.headline: Pejorative Parallels
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   As the author of books for young adults, I would like to respond to Doris Grumbach's review of "Sarah Orne Jewett: A Writer's Life" (May 23). The reviewer compared Elizabeth Silverthorne's biography to a young-adult book, claiming that both are "stripped down" and "simplistic." There are clunkers in any genre of writing. When casting about for a pejorative parallel, however, Ms. Grumbach should have picked a literary field with which she has had more experience. Those familiar with young adults and their literature know that a lower age level does not mean a lower level of quality.

nytimes_articles.abstract: Paring Navy installations that support the fleet, a Presidential commission voted today to close large naval maintenance depots in California, Florida and Virginia that employ nearly 12,000 civilian workers.    On the panel's fourth day of final deliberations on 238 installations, the commission voted to shut down 21 installations and keep open 32 others, while 9 were either pared back or expanded.

nytimes_articles.headline: An Avoidable Case Of Double Dummy
nytimes_articles.abstract: A PLAYER may see one or more of an opponent's cards deliberately, or accidentally, or deliberately-accidentally. Peeking is, of course, improper, but has been known to happen. The tall player with good peripheral vision has a potential advantage. But an opponent who leans forward and holds his cards sloppily is a nuisance. A warning is in order, but after that, most would agree that the exposing player should suffer the consequences.   There is also the case of a player who deliberately shows his cards to an opponent. This sometimes happens late in the play, in an effort to convince an opponent that all roads lead to Rome. But on the diagramed deal from the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams in Pasadena, Calif., in March, 1992, Bob Levin, a former world champion, in the South seat showed his cards to West before the opening lead.

Espionage plays a part in THE SILENCER, by the Glasgow-born Israeli author Simon Louvish (Interlink Books/Interlink Publishing, cloth, $24.95; paper, $10.95), and so do satire, humor, political analysis, Israeli-Arab relationships, the meaning of Jewishness, the terrors of religious fanaticism (Israeli as well as Arab), Realpolitik, Surrealism -- you name it.

nytimes_articles.headline: How Many Need Special Access to Transit?
nytimes_articles.abstract: DETERMINING the number of people with disabilities who use the Long Island Rail Road is difficult. The L.I.R.R. does not keep figures. Neither do advocacy groups.   But they agree that the number is probably small, because most people who use the train system go through Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan, which, despite continuing renovations, is still inaccessible to people in wheelchairs.

nytimes_articles.headline: Motown Comes to Katonah
nytimes_articles.abstract: A benefit at Caramoor Center for Music and the Arts, June 19.

nytimes_articles.headline: Commercial Property: Ladies' Mile; From the Carriage Trade to the Category Killers
nytimes_articles.abstract: IT used to be the Ladies' Mile, the place where affluent women went to buy fashionable clothes. It included Hugh O'Neill, B. Altman, Siegel-Cooper and other department stores that catered to the carriage trade.   Today, after decades of catering to virtually no one save the odd buyer of a quick lunch or piece of hardware, part of that once-fashionable strip -- from 17th to 23d Street on Avenue of the Americas -- is again turning into a major retail area. But this time, its target market is not the free-spending ladies who lunch (and shop); it is the bargain hunters.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Waif Look: A Dissent
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Elizabeth Kaye's cover story on the return of the waif model, "So Weak, So Powerful," is full of holes. She seems to claim that women crave these images -- "what women want is at odds with what they say they want." Excuse me, but an image appearing in British Vogue has no correlation to what women want. Magazines like Vogue do not reflect women's needs. They represent a manipulative and multibillion-dollar fashion industry.

nytimes_articles.headline: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
nytimes_articles.abstract: SOCIAL CRITICISM THE LAST INNOCENT WHITE MAN IN AMERICA And Other Writings. By John Leonard. New Press, $21.95.

nytimes_articles.headline: Ancestral Home Of Yellowed Celery
nytimes_articles.abstract: I had to laugh reading the May 30 Montclair Journal, "Plan for Farmers' Market in Center of Town Upsets Grocers." You print without a trace of skepticism the bizarre notion, promulgated by close-knit local merchants, that competition is "unethical and unfair" in the grocery business.   It's especially amusing to those of us who for years have been complaining about low-quality supermarkets and the lack of decent produce in this area -- where real-estate prices have long discouraged the kind of freewheeling competition in the grocery business that provides most other Americans with access to a range of quality produce.

nytimes_articles.headline: Busting the Mafia: Italy Advances in War on Crime
nytimes_articles.abstract: By 4 A.M. the 16 armed law enforcement officers had slipped through the orange grove and encircled the farmhouse. As the sun rose over Sicily an hour or so later, they moved in, smashing down a door to burst into a kitchen and then swarm into the bedrooms.    What happened next was almost an anticlimax.

nytimes_articles.headline: Elisabeth Schupf, Ashley Lonsdale
nytimes_articles.abstract: Elisabeth Anne Schupf, a daughter of Harriet Warm of Shaker Heights, Ohio, and New York, and Axel Schupf of New York, was married yesterday to Duncan Ashley Lonsdale, a son of Indira Lonsdale of Columbia, S.C., and Kenneth Lonsdale of Akron, Ohio. Schupf & Company, investment advisors in New York, and is the chairman of the Jewish Museum in New York.

nytimes_articles.headline: 8 Captives Are Freed In Brooklyn
nytimes_articles.abstract: A Chinese woman found weeping on a Brooklyn street early Friday led the police to a house in Sheepshead Bay where she and eight other immigrants had been held captive, some for as long as half a year, the police said yesterday.   The 21-year-old woman told detectives she was kidnapped from Kennedy International Airport a week ago, robbed of $300 and repeatedly raped by her captors. Other victims said they were regularly beaten.

nytimes_articles.headline: Farce Within Farce: Michael Frayn's 'Noises Off'
nytimes_articles.abstract: "NOISES OFF" is about a provincial English repertory company touring in a thoroughly tacky sex comedy called "Nothing On." Much acknowledged and justly so, the farce within a farce is the flip side of Michael Frayn, an amazingly protean playwright ("The Benefactors," a drama about social reform, was a 1985 hit on Broadway), novelist ("Now You Know," a portentous comedy about bureaucracies was published this year), adapter (of French and Russian authors, mostly Chekhov) and journalist.   For all Mr. Frayn's braininess and versatility, it is this 1982 theater piece, recently mauled in a movie version, for which he remains best known. What "Noises Off" says about a dying-out genre is relevant to the dire state of summer stock and what it shows of actors and a director gone haywire makes a final statement, preposterous and inarguable, about the theater at its craziest.

nytimes_articles.headline: How Scandal Undercut Japan's Smug Leaders
nytimes_articles.abstract: For the aging postwar rulers of Japan, the end began with a shady real estate deal: nothing too big, just a sleek glass office building in front of Kawasaki Station.    To construct the building on such a choice location in the mid-1980's, the president of a high-flying company called Recruit passed enormous amounts of unlisted stock in his company to powerful members of the governing Liberal Democratic Party.

nytimes_articles.headline: Nancy Blum, Howard Feinglass
nytimes_articles.abstract: Anita Kaskel Roe and Dr. Morton Blum, both of New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Lynn Blum, to Howard Paul Feinglass, the son of Leonard Feinglass and Elaine Feinglass, both of Baltimore. A July wedding is planned.   Miss Blum, 27, graduated from Syracuse University. Her father, a consultant in asset management, retired as an attending physician in the department of medicine and gastroenterology at Lenox Hill Hospital in New York. Her mother is an executive vice president of the Carol Management Corporation in New York, real estate developers and owners of the Doral hotel chain. The bride's maternal grandfather, the late Alfred L. Kaskel, founded the corporation.

nytimes_articles.headline: Savoring the Appeal of Japanese Treats
nytimes_articles.abstract: IT IS 8 o'clock on a Saturday night and the Nagashima restaurant in Jericho is jammed. At a small table in the corner, two burly young men share sushi. Nearby a group of spirited teen-agers sip miso soup, and a family with young children devours a fresh-fruit platter.   Nagashima is an especially appealing and deservedly popular Japanese restaurant. It is a hit not only with health-conscious Americans, but also with huge numbers of Japanese.

nytimes_articles.headline:
The View From: White Plains;
Brokering a Marriage Between the Arts and Business
nytimes_articles.abstract:
WANTED: Energetic corporate types, preferably well versed in marketing or financial management, to volunteer services to arts organizations. No pay, but job has other rewards. Contact Westchester Arts Council, 428-4220.

In the coming months, the Arts Council will, in the words of its executive director, Janet T. Langsam, be acting as a "marriage broker" between the arts and business. Through a national program known as Business Volunteers for the Arts, it is seeking volunteers to lend their expertise to arts organizations. An accountant, for example, might balance the books of a theater company; a marketing specialist might plan a public relations campaign for a music school.

nytimes_articles.headline: Turkey Has Far to Go on Human Rights
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   "Christopher Gives Turks Plan to End Rights Abuses" (news article, June 13) reports from Ankara that Secretary of State Warren Christopher has asked Turkish leaders to cooperate with a detailed United States proposal to help end widespread human rights abuses in Turkey. nytimes_articles.abstract:

nytimes_articles.headline: Sports of The Times; Brits Enjoy a Better Week Than Bumbling Mets
nytimes_articles.abstract: Homesickness washes over the visting New Yorker. It is not the burgers they insist upon selling, nor is it the corn on the cob and the hot dogs the pubs drag out to celebrate the Fourth of July. What makes the New Yorker miss home so much is the bark of the pack, hot on the whiff of failure.   There is no Mike and there is no Mad Dog, at least not on my civilized BBC radio band, but they do have their rabid tabloids here, and they are yowling about the failure of the national cricket team and the national soccer team. Two sports they invented, by the way.

nytimes_articles.headline: Nigerian Military Ruler Announces New Elections
nytimes_articles.abstract: Nigeria's military leader, Gen, Ibrahim Babangida, announced tonight that there would be a new presidential election with new candidates to replace the June 12 vote that he annulled three days ago.   In a nationwide address, General Babangida did not say exactly when the new election would be held, or how it would be conducted. But he emphasized that the two previous candidates -- Moshood Abiola of the Social Democrats and Bashir Tofa of the National Republican Convention -- had disqualified themselves from running again because of what he called their flagrant abuse of Nigeria's election laws.

nytimes_articles.headline: When Tired Plants Need a Pick-Me-Up

If it is not, there may be good reasons. It is possible that the plants are simply hungry, and the simplest solution is application of a plant fertilizer.   If the soil is of poor quality, lack of proper nutrition may be the cause of spindly growth and lack of strong flowers. But if the soil is in good condition, these starvation conditions should not exist and can be easily remedied.

nytimes_articles.headline: Secular and Sacred Images In Cold Spring a Puzzlement
nytimes_articles.abstract: TO say that Jerald Frampton's Cibachromes, on view at the John Froats Gallery, here, could prompt a visit to the ophthalmologist is not a wisecrack but rather a note of caution. After all, a series of blurred photographs is an unsettling experience, all the more so when the works are tableaux. Add to that the show's title, "True Tales of Jesus," which may or may not be ironic -- the artist himself does not seem sure.   The Savior appears in only 3 of these 24 scenes: in one He sits, a berobed figure with a flower in his hair and arms outstretched, in the company of two small children; in another, He is airborne over a Classical temple to the apparent surprise of a Roman centurion; and in a third image He stands beside a leafless tree with a bird. Otherwise, the cast consists of cowboys, boxers, animals and prehistoric figures clad in skins -- all deployed in a doll's landscape, except when they are portents in the sky.

nytimes_articles.headline: Nassau Golf Clubs Get $8 Million Rebate
nytimes_articles.abstract:
THE 34 golf clubs in Nassau County are beginning to receive tax refunds totaling an estimated $8 million, a result of their appeal of a revaluation of their property in 1986. Although the settlement is large the clubs' appeal was by no means unusual. 

Last month a record 48,000 protests were filed with the County Board of Assessment Review, all but 13,000 from homeowners, according to the chairman of the board, Abe Seldin. That was a 20 percent increase over the 40,000 protests in 1992.

"Residential protests are up, because there are almost 100 law firms out there soliciting practically every homeowner in Nassau County," County Attorney Robert W. Schmidt said. "Between 75 and 90 percent of the homeowners who protest their assessment get an adjustment."

Such adjustments, he added, do not generally result in a large tax cut, because many neighbors have also usually applied for and received reductions.

"It's like a tube of toothpaste," said a lawyer, Saul Fenchel of Garden City, who represented some of the golf clubs. "If you squeeze one end, it has to give out at the other."

He said that the same amount of money still had to be raised through taxes to support government and that school districts received 55 to 60 percent of the property taxes collected by the county. The districts have built-in expenses like teachers' salaries and maintenance that have to be met. Unless cuts are made, Mr. Fenchel said, reductions in assessments mean increases in tax rates. 

Although the $8 million refund sounds large, Mr. Schmidt said, it "is just a pebble" in the total financial picture of Nassau. He said the county had spent $100,000 defending its case, calling in golf experts and architects to justify the original assessments.  The county based its judgments on the premise that using the land as a golf course was temporary and that its main and future use would be for residential development, which classified as the "highest and best use."

Mr. Schmidt added that he did not believe that the court decision against the county would have effects outside Nassau.

Another lawyer who represented the clubs, Jay M. Herman of Mineola, said he "wouldn't characterize it as an insignificant case." He pointed out that the executive director of the Long Island Regional Planning Board, Lee E. Koppelman, "testified in our behalf against the county."

"It may have been the only time he testified for a private party," Mr. Herman said.

Mr. Herman said he had received telephone calls from lawyers outside Nassau asking for copies of the decision, Justice Frank S. Rossetti of State Supreme Court in Mineola on June 4, 1991, on the taxes of the 130-acre New Country Club of Garden City. He wrote that a decision by the county in 1986 to assess golf clubs as though they were residential developments was "contrary to statutory and other fundamental principles of assessment valuation." Justice Rossetti directed that his decision be the basis for other clubs in the county.

The Town of Southampton used the decision as guidance last year, when it completed a townwide reassessment, said Assessor Edward T. Deyermond, who added: 

"That court decision was one of the most widely disseminated decisions ever. We took it into account when we decided not to use an assessment based upon the highest and best use of the land, but rather, to determine the assessment rate based on potential income from the clubs."

As a result of the new rate, Mr. Deyermond said, some courses that had been assessed at $200 an acre were now as high as $1,500 an acre. As might be expected, he said, lawyers have already filed notices of intent to challenge the reassessments in court.

In the Nassau case the lawyers for the New Country Club showed that the Village of Garden City had a moratorium that precluded housing on the golf course. Justice Rossetti noted that Mr. Koppelman had testified that residential use was "not probable in the foreseeable future."

In arriving at his decision, Justice Rossetti said, he had considered "the importance of open land to Long Island's water supply (particularly its sole-source aquifer) and the deleterious effects to it and other necessary municipal services (such as garbage, traffic and recreation) from overdevelopment, particularly in an area such as Garden City, which is almost completely developed residentially."

"Thus," the decision added, "while the golf club and other large-tract sales adduced by respondents admittedly indicated the strength of the demand for residential land in Nassau County, the many obstacles shown by petitioner evinced the reasonable probability that the subject golf course would not obtain all the approvals necessary within the reasonably foreseeable future."

A lawyer for the club, Andrew G. Cangemi of Garden City, said that argument was crucial. "You can't assess golf clubs based upon their potential use because of the vagaries of local governments," Mr. Cangemi said. 
Settlement With 30 Clubs

 After the decision, the county filed a notice of appeal. Lawyers representing 30 of the 34 clubs negotiated a settlement last year that called for a rollback in the assessments to the 1985 levels and a 25 percent reduction in the refund for each club. A lawyer for the clubs, Adolph Koeppel, said the appeal would have taken years, during which the clubs would have had to pay the higher assessments.

One lawyer said the taxes were so high that some clubs had to borrow money to pay them. Mr. Koeppel said the assessments had raised the taxes 60 to 70 percent.

The four clubs not in the suit had their rates lowered to the 1985 levels and agreed to have their refunds cut 28 percent, Mr. Schmidt said.

The difference between the 1986 and 1985 rates is striking, according to Mr. Cangemi. Under the revaluation, he said, the Glen Head Country Club paid $355,000 in taxes. Under the 1985 rate it paid $246,000 in taxes last year, saving more than $100,000.

A spokesman for the 260-acre Glen Oaks Country Club in Old Westbury, which participated in the suit and received a $504,000 refund, called it a windfall, but said the "best part is the assessment reduction we'll have from now on."

"We have a huge payroll and a $6 million budget, and this refund will allow us not to have to lay off people," the spokesman said. "Sales are down because of the economy, which has been a real drag on the clubs. This decision is a benefit for everybody."

But the general manager of the Glen Head Country Club in Glen Head, Kevin F. Murphy, said: "We don't consider it a windfall, but a disgrace that we had to pay our members' hard-earned dues money to get back money that was ours to begin with."

"The only guys who made out were the attorneys," Mr. Murphy said.  "They got a fourth of the refund."

Despite the rollbacks, county officials said, there has generally not been a significant increase in tax rates stemming from the case.

In Jericho, School Superintendent Robert Manheimer said that assessments in his district were down $700,000 last and that the Glen Oaks reduction might have been a major reason. But that loss, he said, was offset by increased state aid and new construction.

Dr. Manheimer said that he prepared the budget for next year based on a belief that assessments would be flat, but that he would not know whether he was right until the Board of Assessment Review ruled on the protests and released its figures on Aug. 1. If he is wrong and assessments are down, he added, the tax rate might have to rise.
First Postwar Decline

 "If over the next few years there is a continuing drop in assessments because of the appeals," Dr. Manheimer said, "it is going to have to be reflected in higher tax rates, unless we decrease expenditures." 

Assessments in Nassau County last year dropped for the first time since World War II, according to Mr. Seldin. He attributed that to steady growth, which he said has been drying up and no longer offset reductions in assessments that have been routinely granted since a court decision in 1978 permitted assessments to fluctuate based on market values.

The reductions for the golf clubs, Mr. Seldin said, were taken into account when the county reduced the assessment roll last year, from $4,099,305,806 to $4,072,451,791. Another factor was a new depreciation system for utilities. Although it will be two months before the new as

Before the assessments were finalized last year, Mr. Seldin said, he had estimated a $9,400,000 increase in the rate. The final figure was a decrease of $26,854,000. He said he had estimated a $20,000 increase in the rate this year, but that the 48,000 protests will more than wipe that out.

A spokesman for Mr. Seldin, Thomas Preston, said that from 1978 to 1991, the latest available totals, the county refunded $338.6 million. The largest year for refunds was 1985, with $41.1 million. In 1991, $32.2 million was refunded.

Mr. Schmidt said that the refunds had been averaging $25 million a year and that although the school districts received more than half of that, Nassau was liable for the reimbursement under the County Charter. 

That, however, is not the case in Suffolk County, where the 10 towns collect property taxes. Refunds in Suffolk have to be shared by the agencies that received the revenue. "It's a no-man's land out there in Suffolk," Mr. Schmidt said. "It's the Wild West."

Nassau has gone to Albany to try to persuade lawmakers to permit it to use that system. But, Mr. Schmidt said, strong opposition from Nassau school districts had killed those attempts.

In addition to Glen Oaks, eight other clubs have received refunds, and the others will receive their shortly, a spokesman for County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta said. 

Larger refunds went to the Atlantic Beach Club, $445,000; Glen Head, $295,000; the North Hempstead Country Club in Port Washington, $292,000, and the Rockville Country Club in Rockville Centre, $230,000.

nytimes_articles.headline: One-Game Spot A Better Format
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Sports Editor:   Dave Anderson recently decried the proposed three-tier wild-card playoff format for baseball ("When Second Best Is Not Near the Best," The Times, May 16). He demonstrated that much of the excitement and urgency of the divisional pennant races would be lost if such a system were enacted. Several scenarios were presented showing how a team may choose to glide to a second-place finish rather than strive for first place. After all, the only advantage to finishing first would be a one-game home field advantage in the first round of a best three--of-five playoff with the second-place team.

nytimes_articles.headline: Manor Houses
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor: Having seen most of the moated castles in the article "England's Moated Manor Houses" (May 2) I can say they are well worth visiting. Bodiam Castle is a tantalizing ruin; I could almost see the knights on white horses riding across the causeway. Leeds Castle, with the largest moat, was very grand. But Ightham Mote evoked strong imaginings of what life in a moated manor was like. I can still recall the hound dog's house in the courtyard, a cellar that had a window opening onto the moat and a comfortable looking sitting room. Little Moreton Hall is so well cared for that it's hard to believe it was built before Columbus discovered America.

nytimes_articles.headline: Is Lollapalooza Losing Its Outsider Status?
nytimes_articles.abstract: The people who put on the Woodstock festival were smart: They didn't try an annual sequel. Of course, after Woodstock they were broke. The 1991 Lollapalooza Festival, which turned the farewell tour by Jane's Addiction into an alternative-rock showcase and quasi-political sideshow, made a profit, as did its 1992 follow-up. So a third annual Lollapalooza was inevitable; it started at Thunderbird Stadium on June 18 and reaches the New York area (actually, Stanhope, N.J.) on July 12, 13 and 16.    Lollapalooza '93 places a new lineup of bands within the same setup as the 1992 version: a big stage and a smaller stage, a gathering of food and clothing vendors, hints (though, this year, little more) of political engagement. On the big stage are Primus, Alice in Chains, Dinosaur Jr., Fishbone, Arrested Development, Front 242, Rage Against the Machine and Babes in Toyland (or, for the second part of the tour, Tool); the four bands on the smaller stage will change throughout the tour. Because it kept last year's format with some shrinking margins -- there's no freak show, a big part of Lollapalooza '92 -- the opening show of Lollapalooza '93 was a slight letdown. But for the moment, it's still the closest thing to an alternative-rock summit for both performers and audience.

nytimes_articles.headline: Atonal, of Course, But Deep Down He's Got Rhythm
nytimes_articles.abstract: "We are bringing them the plague," Sigmund Freud supposedly remarked as his ship docked in New York and delivered psychoanalysis to America. Arnold Schoenberg might have said something similar when he showed up in California in 1934 with his "system for composing in 12 tones." In the postwar era, the 12-tone system swiftly spread through the American compositional community, and in the 1950's and 60's an even more difficult phenomenon called Serialism took hold.    Schoenberg's strict method, ordering the 12 pitches of the scale in nonrepeating atonal rows, was exhilarating therapy for composers beset by a multiplicity of stylistic choices. The plague was on audiences, who detested the jumbled, athematic textures common to the idiom. Schoenberg's conviction that his new system would replace the old proved to be foolish. The 12-tone order failed to make atonality second nature; at the same time, it tamed atonality's unnatural force.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Crossroads Of History on Italy's Heel
nytimes_articles.abstract:
ALONG the southeastern coast of Italy, a little more than a quarter of the way up the Italian boot, a spur of land juts into the Adriatic Sea, looking out across the clear blue-green waters that separate western Europe from the Byzantine east. It is a chalky limestone massif known as the Promontorio del Gargano, or Gargano Peninsula, and it offers many of the finest sandy bathing beaches, spectacular seaside vistas, and some of the most beautiful mountainous forests in the whole of Italy.

Yet the Gargano, situated in the northeast of the economically underdeveloped Apulia, has until recently been held in comparatively low esteem, except by budget-conscious Italian campers. The beneficial result of this is that the small villages along its 65 miles of coastline still retain their character and provincial charm. Best of all, prices for accommodations are less than half of what you would pay in other parts of Italy, generally an expensive place to visit.

Whitesbog Journal;
In Abandoned Village, Twofold Restoration
nytimes_articles.abstract:
THE narrow, poorly paved road just off Route 530 in Pemberton Township meanders for about a half-mile before it ends at what might be the movie set for a Western ghost town. The cluster of about a dozen empty, weathered cedar-shingled buildings, some of them homes with sagging porches, others deserted warehouses, was once a thriving turn-of-the-century agricultural village known as Whitesbog. As many as 600 workers and their families lived there amid 3,000 acres of forests, bogs and cedar swamps in the New Jersey Pine Barrens.

But Whitesbog, which began as an experimental cranberry farm in 1857, is not as ghostly as it might appear. The site is undergoing a restoration, and much of the work is being done by teen-agers on probation as part of a nine-year-old vocational program coordinated by the New Jersey Department of Corrections. They are there to rebuild their own lives along with the decaying buildings of Whitesbog.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Best, or Maybe Worst, Of the Talk-Show World
nytimes_articles.abstract: Greg Kinnear thought he had seen it all. As the host of "Talk Soup," a half-hour cable program that consists of excerpts from television talk shows, Mr. Kinnear had witnessed some of the most outrageous moments in the history of daytime television.    Every weekday, the "Talk Soup" producers comb through about 20 talk programs and select a brief segment from each; 10 segments make it into each half-hour. Mr. Kinnear had been exposed to some real doozies. He had seen Lulu and Topsy Curvy, two stripper sisters who claimed, on "Sally Jessy Raphael," to have the biggest breasts in America. He had watched in amazement as a man on "The Montel Williams Show" described having been raped by an alien. He had seen a verbal catfight between Joan Rivers and Jessica Hahn and an out-and-out brawl between Geraldo Rivera and a member of the Ku Klux Klan. No, there wasn't much left in the realm of talk-show infamy that could surprise Mr. Kinnear.

nytimes_articles.headline: Editors' Note
nytimes_articles.abstract: A review in the Times Book Review on May 23 discussed "Faith in a Seed: 'The Dispersion of Seeds' and Other Late Natural History Writings," by Henry D. Thoreau, edited by Bradley P. Dean. The review -- by William Howarth, author of "The Book of Concord: Thoreau's Life as a Writer" -- was mixed: it spoke well of the "grooming" of the material by its editor, and praised Thoreau's thoughtfulness, his powers of observation and his ecological insights. It also characterized the text as resembling "a set of working notes" more than a book, and said the volume ignored much prior scholarship.   After the review appeared, senior editors of the Book Review learned that before accepting the assignment, Mr. Howarth had expressed reservations about "Faith in a Seed" to its publisher, and had disclosed that fact to the Book Review.

nytimes_articles.headline: Two Types of Lasers Available on L.I.
nytimes_articles.abstract: In reference to "Laser Surgery Making Inroads on L.I."  [ April 18 ] , we would like to clarify several issues concerning dermatologic laser surgery. The pulsed-dye laser is one of several selective vascular-lesion lasers capable of treating port-wine stains, hemangiomas, facial spider veins and cherry angiomas. Another is the copper-vapor laser, which also utilizes yellow light to specifically target red blood vessels. Presently, there are two pulsed-dye and two copper-vapor lasers available on Long Island. Different vascular lesions may respond better to one or the other. No laser has been proven safe and effective for the treatment of spider veins on the legs.   Regarding the removal of pigmented lesions and tattoos, three lasers have received F.D.A. approval. One, the q-switched ruby laser, was discussed in your article. Another, the q-switched Nd-YAG laser, utilized a similar q-switched technique and has been shown to be equally successful in the removal of brown spots and tattoos. Currently two of these lasers are located on Long Island. The copper-vapor laser can also erase certain benign pigmented lesions. However it does not treat tattoos.

nytimes_articles.abstract: In the ancient souks and the new office buildings of this city, growing numbers of people are now saying openly what was once unspeakable: peace with Israel is coming, and it is time to think about Syria's role in the Middle East after a peace agreement is signed.   While such private pronouncements are sharply at odds with the statements of the Syrian Government, which continues to accuse Israel of intransigence at peace talks in Washington, they are a clear measure of the degree to which the popular mood and economic reality seem to be shifting within Syria, which has long been the most hostile to Israel of the front-line Arab countries.

nytimes_articles.headline: Across the Top of L.A.
nytimes_articles.abstract:
LOS ANGELES is a city about which much has been said, at once the butt of jokes and America's fabled, urban Bird of Paradise. It is a sprawling city -- 450 square miles, with a population of 3.5 million -- bordered by the Pacific Ocean on the west, thinning out to a seemingly endless suburban frontier on the south, and rimmed on the north and east by a tangle of mountain ranges. Congested highways link its disparate parts without providing a sense of what lies in between. It can be a daunting, confusing place, too much to take in. But for those who seek the big picture, there is a road that begins to clarify L.A.

Mulholland Highway ribbons across the crest of the Santa Monica Mountains, the east-west tending range that separates the Los Angeles basin from the San Fernando Valley. Rising to about 3,000 feet, these are not high mountains, but they are strategically placed, beginning near Dodger Stadium and ending at the Pacific Ocean in Malibu (unless you count those partly submerged peaks that are the Channel Islands). Driving Mulholland's sinuous 55-mile course is the enterprise of one very busy day. Parks and scenic overlooks line the way, and the city unrolls on either side of you like an animated map. Close at hand on the eastern end are the "ego homes" of the rich and famous, clawing their way up the steep, chaparral-covered flanks of a swatch of the Santa Monicas called the Hollywood Hills. Farther west, Mulholland tightrope-walks across Sepulveda Pass and the San Diego Freeway, diminishes to dirt for nine miles above Encino, then emerges paved again, taking travelers on a wild, wheel-gripping ride through the mostly undeveloped heart of the mountains. As a scenic parkway, Mulholland abjures commercial development. However, food and fuel are available on any of the arteries that intersect it and lead down to the nonstop blandishments of Ventura Boulevard in the Valley or those siren thoroughfares to the south, Sunset and Hollywood.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Short Season for Apricots
nytimes_articles.abstract: FOR the connoisseur of fresh apricots, an all-too-brief season, from mid-June to mid-July, is often full of frustration. Unlike Goldilocks, anyone trying to find the lush, velvety fruits when they are neither too hard nor too soft but just right may have trouble.   It's the familiar yet tiresome story of fruit that is at its best when tree ripened but which rarely comes to market in that condition. Few local growers have apricots to harvest, so they are shipped from California, the source of most apricots, and both time and safe handling preclude picking the fruit at its peak.

Eclectic Fare and a View by the Shore
nytimes_articles.abstract:
LABRADOR LOUNGE is the name, and whimsy is the game at this raffish new eating place across the street from the beach in Belmar. With an exterior that's painted swimming-pool green, and a 1950's knotty-pine rec room ambiance, coupled with a sushi bar and a collegiate staff in Bermuda shorts, this Monmouth County spot obviously doesn't take itself too seriously. 

What's funky and young-spirited to some, however, may seem cramped and noisy to others, and the copious portions of eclectic fare -- from turkey burgers to halibut en papillote -- may strike some as a rather clumsily executed mishmash. But given the modest menu prices, the handful of tasty dishes and the lighthearted suitability to its locale, Labrador Lounge is a diverting addition.

nytimes_articles.headline: Poll Finds Tide of Immigration Brings Hostility

nytimes_articles.headline:
BACKTALK;
No Answer for a Broken Leg, No Solace for a Broken Heart
nytimes_articles.abstract:
In the 21 years I have owned and raced thoroughbreds I've known all the emotions the sport can provide: the breathless anticipation moments before the gate opens, the disappointment of losing with an odds-on favorite and the utter exhilaration of winning a Triple Crown race. Yet in all those years nothing has been as emotionally wrenching as what I've experienced since 5:32 P.M., June 5, when Prairie Bayou took a tragic misstep in the early stages of the Belmont Stakes and broke his left front leg.

Even before I got to Prairie Bayou on the Belmont backstretch, saw the extent of his injuries and heard the hopeless prognosis from the veterinarians, the battle with my emotions was under way. Despite being told that never in history had a horse injured in this fashion been saved I wondered if a new medical technique could be tried. At the least, maybe we could learn something to save the next injured horse. Still, the decision had to be made quickly; there could be no procrastination.
Some Injuries Defy Medical Science

 I was in the van looking into the panicked eyes of the horse as his groom, trainer, vet, assistant trainer and members of the Belmont emergency staff worked to hold him upright, keeping him still and off his shattered leg. It was in this environment that I became convinced that no amount of money or the 50-plus years of veterinary experience that surrounded me could save Prairie Bayou's life and I faced the stark reality that there are some injuries that defy medical science. The decision to put Prairie Bayou to sleep was the most humane option and I chose it. It was my decision to make.

nytimes_articles.headline: Yet Another Heritage
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Edward Rothstein's essay on folk music, "60's 'Folk' Is Giving Up the Ghost"  [ May 30 ] , wasn't quite complete. Yes, by 1970 the folk-music movement was finished. But it left a heritage Mr. Rothstein didn't mention. Early in the 60's, folk music seeped into rock-and-roll, changing rock in ways we now take for granted. Thanks to folk music's influence, rock singers now write their own songs, and they don't have to be love songs, as almost all pre-folk rock songs were; in fact, they're often political, like many 50's and 60's folk songs.

nytimes_articles.headline: Food Store's Low Road To the Top of the Line
nytimes_articles.abstract: As a law student, Andrew Arons began a wildly successful specialty food importing business, Flying Foods. He may or may not have introduced radicchio to the American table, as he claims, but by the time he he sold the company to Kraft Foods in 1987 for $8 million there was no denying his knowledge of the most arcane aspects of the food business.    That sale gave him money and time to figure out his next gambit in the gourmet game, and he began a long intellectual prowl. He believes he saw the light in an aisle in a Wal-Mart, though it might have been Kmart. The lesson was that odd-colored baby vegetables and the other goods he knew best could be turned over rapidly when sold at a low margin in a no-frills environment.

nytimes_articles.headline: In Rural Jails, Haitians Suffer From Isolation
nytimes_articles.abstract: In the middle of an isolated Louisiana parish, 18 dejected Haitian refugees sit in two dank, windowless jail cells, a thousand miles from the company of their countrymen at a detention center in Florida, which Federal authorities say is too crowded to house them.   Looking back on the uncertain charms of nearly six months in a rural Louisiana jail -- watery grits and overcooked rice as part of typical prison fare, metal bunks with thin pallets, and, for seven female refugees in the parish's jail for women, unwelcome sexual advances from local inmates -- several Haitians yearned in recent interviews for the Krome Avenue Detention Immigration Facility in Miami, even though Haitians there have complained of beatings and harassment. One even wants to go home.

nytimes_articles.headline: Star of Cozzene Beats (Ties) Lure

And it got both yesterday when Star of Cozzene ran down Lure in the homestretch to win the $500,000 Caesar's International at the Atlantic City Race Course and tie their sizzling rivalry at two victories apiece.   The two speed horses, the best on grass and maybe the best on any surface, renewed their competition just half an hour after the colt Great Navigator joined the growing casualty list of thoroughbreds when he suffered a broken ankle bone during the Jersey Shore Breeders' Cup. The accident was said by the track's veterinarians to be career threatening but probably not life threatening, and the horse was taken to the hospital with a splint and brace on his left foreleg.

nytimes_articles.headline: At Home Abroad; Time to Change
nytimes_articles.abstract: When hundreds of right-wing whites the other day smashed into the hall where South Africa's future is being negotiated, they achieved a paradoxical result. They made clear how urgently necessary it is to conclude the talks and move toward a democratic government that has the legitimacy to govern.   A new South Africa has been trying to emerge for more than three years now. But there was the old, unchanged: a gun-toting white mob hardly challenged by the police, who would surely have used at least tear gas and probably weapons against a black protest half as violent.

nytimes_articles.headline: Cliffhanger: Can Early Movies Be Saved in Time?
nytimes_articles.abstract: The art of the cinema may be forever, but the film stock is not. A four-volume report released late last week by the Library of Congress offers, for the first time, a comprehensive survey of film preservation in the United States by film studios, archives and individuals.    Entitled "Film Preservation 1993: A Study of the Current State of American Film Preservation," the report describes a losing battle against time, with inadequately financed preservationists racing to fend off the threat posed by deterioration of film stock and to reconstruct the original versions of films that have been altered over time.

Should his spending be credited to his new campaign or to his failed one?   Sounds like a technicality, but the impact of the board's decision will be anything but technical. nytimes_articles.abstract: Sharon Klein, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Klein of Roslyn Heights, L.I., was married yesterday to Elliott Scott Dobin, the son of Mrs. Jack Dobin of New York and the late Mr. Dobin. Rabbi Miriam Ancis performed the ceremony at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

nytimes_articles.headline: RAID ON BAGHDAD: Reaction; European Allies Are Giving Strong Backing to U.S. Raid
nytimes_articles.abstract: With rare unanimity, the European allies reacted with approval today to the United States missile strike against Iraq.    Britain, Italy and Germany, all of whose leaders were apparently informed about the plans shortly before the strike began, all gave strong backing to the move today despite reports of civilian casualties.

nytimes_articles.headline: Open the G-7's Doors To This Asian Symbol
nytimes_articles.abstract: It is time to breathe a bit of life into that tired old circus, the annual Group of Seven summit meeting. Next month, members of this self-appointed group will sit around in Tokyo, where the host nation and the leaders of the other big industrialized nat

nytimes_articles.headline: SHEIK WAS AWARE OF BOMBING PLOT, U.S. OFFICIALS SAY
nytimes_articles.abstract: Federal law-enforcement authorities in New York concluded that Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman, the radical Egyptian cleric, knew details of the plot to detonate bombs across the city and assassinate several officials but were waved off of arresting him at the last minute by the Clinton Administration, Government officials said today.   The officials described the decision -- debated in a series of meetings last Tuesday -- as a hairline call ultimately decided by Attorney General Janet Reno on legal and tactical grounds, including Mr. Abdel Rahman's usefulness as a powerful lens through which authorities examined the murky and violent world of Islamic extremism. Evidence Called 'Fuzzy'    Moreover, as they considered preparing an arrest complaint, the officials concluded that some of the evidence against the sheik was "fuzzy," as one put it, although investigators were convinced -- on the basis of electronic monitoring -- that he knew about the plot. Their information was less clear about his precise role and how directly he was involved in specific actions, like selecting targets.

nytimes_articles.headline: RAID ON BAGHDAD: The White House; Administration Finds Just Keeping a Secret Can Be a Triumph
nytimes_articles.abstract: The unexpected missile strike against Iraq's intelligence headquarters was a result of weeks of intensive planning so secret that no more than five top White House aides had any knowledge of the discussions, Clinton Adminstration officials said today.   By concealing the conclusion that Baghdad was responsible for an assassination plot against George Bush during his visit to Kuwait in April, aides provided a veil of secrecy that gave President Clinton the advantage of surprise when military retribution came. It also helped him appear decisive and resolute in his most significant action yet as Commander in Chief.

nytimes_articles.headline: Thousands March in a Celebration of Gay Pride
nytimes_articles.abstract: With their fists raised in solidarity and their voices celebrating their pride, tens of thousands of gay men, lesbians and their supporters strolled and chanted their way down Fifth Avenue yesterday in a sprawling march that underscored the striking range of gay life in New York City.   Gay social workers, gay soccer players, gay gospel singers, gay Republicans, gay mothers, gay Harlemites, -- they all came together on a humid afternoon for the 24th annual march, which took on an added significance this year because of President Clinton's proposal to allow homosexuals to serve in the military. What Gay America Looks Like    "I feel so moved emotionally," Miriam Ben-Shalom, one of the grand marshals of the parade, said as she watched marchers surge down Fifth Avenue and spectators three-deep jostle for views on the sidewalks. "Look at all the people here. This is America. Do you want to see what gay America looks like? Look on this street."

nytimes_articles.headline: Was This Strike Necessary?
nytimes_articles.abstract: It's easy to appreciate the pressures that drove President Clinton to order an early Sunday morning missile attack on an Iraqi intelligence complex in central Baghdad. And no sympathy need be wasted on Saddam Hussein, whose continued defiance of Security Council resolutions makes him, literally, an international outlaw.    Mr. Clinton's show of force won predictably quick endorsement on Capitol Hill and from allied leaders. But the American people need more information about the reasons for and propriety of Mr. Clinton's action. Was this -- as the Administration contends -- a wise use of force, combining the logic of retaliation and the benefit of pre-empting future terrorist strikes?

nytimes_articles.headline: In Detroit Beating Case, Pillory for Cub Reporter
nytimes_articles.abstract: The judge in a police beating trial here has cited a newspaper intern for contempt for telephoning a juror while testimony was still being heard in the case. But in an unusual twist, the judge ordered the intern, a summer employee of The Detroit News, to serve part of his five-day jail sentence in the courtroom dressed in prison garb.   The judge, who had specifically ordered reporters not to speak with jurors, said while sentencing the intern on Friday that he had mistrusted the newspaper since his childhood. During the McCarthy era, the judge's father defended people accused of being Communists and was harshly criticized by the newspaper.

nytimes_articles.headline: This Time, Yankees Hold Onto The Lead
nytimes_articles.abstract: So many delicious chances had drifted away, so many seemingly insurmountable leads had dissipated on this road trip that the Yankees never felt safe. So when Harold Baines hit a harmless two-out grounder to second that suddenly nicked a clump of dirt and rolled up Pat Kelly's arm with the tying run buzzing home from third in the eighth inning today, the Yankees gasped. Not again. Please, not this again.   Their gasps never turned to groans. Instead, they turned to glee when Kelly deftly fielded the tricky grounder that Steve Howe induced and completed the difficult play to maintain the one-run lead. Then the Yankees exhibited some muscle in the ninth inning, blasting the Baltimore bullpen for three runs on Danny Tartabull's monstrous two-run homer and Don Mattingly's double to escape from Camden Yards with a 9-5 victory. Orioles Cooled Off    They could not wait to gloat, and then leave. Fast.

nytimes_articles.headline: Editorial Notebook; The Real Clarence Thomas
nytimes_articles.abstract: "I say to myself every day, there but for the grace of God, go I," said Supreme Court nominee Clarence Thomas. He was telling the Senate at his 1991 confirmation hearing of the feelings he had for the busloads of prisoners he watched daily from his courthouse window. The implication was that a Justice Thomas, up from the dirt poverty of Pin Point, Ga., would look out for the underdog, even a convicted one with few rights.    Yet twice in his two terms on the Court, Justice Thomas has argued in dissent that the Eighth Amendment's ban on cruel and unusual punishments should not protect prison inmates. Last year he objected to relief for a prisoner who had suffered, he said, only minor injuries at the hands of his guards: a split lip, loosened teeth, a broken dental plate and the taunting of a supervisor who warned the guards not to have "too much fun." The other day he objected again when the Court held that a prisoner subjected to the fumes of a chain-smoking cellmate might have a constitutional complaint.
